When cough and lung illness are from cold moistures, and the sick person does not have fever, nor consumption, and the illness is old: then cauterize it (the lesion) with two cauteries above the collarbone in hollow, open places.
Et cauterio alio in medio pectoris inter duas mammillas: et sit cauterium cannulae secundum formam quae praecessit.	 And with another cautery in the middle of the chest between the two breasts: and let the cautery be a tube according to the form that preceded.
Et si uis sit cauterizatio tua punctando cum cauterio, quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma praecessit in punctatione doloris aurium: et sint puncta ex triginta punctis usque quasi ad alia.	 And if your method of cauterization is by pricking with a cautery called Punctum, whose form was previously mentioned in the treatment of ear pain: and let the pricks be from thirty pricks up to others (similar).
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it (the lesion) with what was previously used, until it is healed.
Et iam sit cauterium habens tres ramos: secundum hanc formam.	 And now let the cautery have three branches: according to this form.
Quare alleuiatur cum eo cauterizatio, quando tu facis cum eo uice una tria Cauteria.	 Why is cauterization avoided when you do it with only one cautery instead of three?
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Titillico, in dislocatione Humeri.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in titillico (a type of lesion), in dislocation of the arm.
Caput XXVII.	 Head Chapter XXVII.
Quando dislocatur caput adiutorii caussa humiditatum, et nonfigitur in hora reditus sui a dislocatione sua, donec sit illud ei consuetudo reditionis, deinde dislocatur a paruo motu, qui accidit sicut nos iam testificauimus illud, tunc oportet ut reducas dislocationem in primis.	 When the head is dislocated due to causes of humidity and it does not return on its own by the hour following the dislocation, until it becomes accustomed to the return, then it should be dislocated slightly, as has been already testified, then it is necessary to reduce the dislocation first.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, aut super latus sanum.	 Then the sick person lies down on his back or on the healthy side.
Deinde eleua cutim, quae est in interiori Titillici ad superiora cum digitis manus tuae sinistrae: et si iunctura dislocatur ad interiora.	 Then the skin that is inside the cheek towards the upper part is to be peeled off with your left hand fingers, and if the dislocation is towards the inner parts.
Deinde igni Cauterium habens duo uerua.	 Then taking two-pronged cautionery by fire.
Cuius forma est haec.	 Its shape is as follows.
Deinde cauteriza cutim, donec penetret eam usque ad latus aliud, et ueniet figura cauterizationis cum quatuor cauteriis.	 Then cauterize the skin until it penetrates to the other side and a figure of four cauteries appears.
Et quandoque fit cauterizatio cum cauterio habente tria uerua, quare fit figura cauterizationis tunc sex cauteriorum: et sunt uerua secundum subtilitatem tentae.	 And sometimes cauterization is done with a cautery having three prongs, for which the figure of cauterization becomes that of six cauteries; and there are prongs according to the subtlety of the test.
Et haec est forma cauterii habentis tria uerua.	 And this is the shape of the cautery having three prongs.
Et quandoque additur super hunc modum unum, quare sunt cauteria octo.	 And sometimes one is added to this method, for which there are eight cauteries.
Deinde pone super cauterium porros contritos cum sale.	 Then put over the cautery softened onions with salt.
Deinde fac adhaerere infirmum tranquillitati, ut non moueatur membrum tempore aliquo, donec confortetur.	 Then make the sick person remain still so that the limb is not moved at any time until it recovers.
Et si dislocatio est ad superiora, et raro fit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super humerum cauterio clauili, aut cauteriis multis punctando.	 If the dislocation is towards the upper parts, and it happens rarely, then cauterize it on the shoulder with a clavicle cautery, or many cauteries piercing.
Nam iunctura firmatur, et remouetur humiditas: et sanatur infirmus.	 For the joint is made firm, and moisture is removed; and the sick person recovers.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Stomachum.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing the stomach.
Caput XXVIII.	 Head Chapter XXVIII.
Quando accidunt in Stomacho frigus et humiditates multae, donec extrahant ipsum a complexione sua, et multiplicentur catarri ad ipsum, et assiduas modos curationis, et non confert: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat crura sua, et manus suas.	 When cold and many humidity occur in the stomach until it separates from its composition, catarrh multiplies towards it and continuous methods of treatment do not help; then it is necessary that the sick person lies down on his back, extends his legs, and his hands.
Deinde cauteriza cum tribus cauteriis, cauterio sub cochleari pectoris quantitate digiti unius cum cauterio clauili, et duobus cauteriis inferius a duobus lateribus cauterii unius, donec ueniat figura cauteriorum triangulata.	 Then cauterize with three cauteries, one cautery under the size of a cowry shell of the breast, one cautery like a nail, and two cauteries below from the sides of one cautery, until the figure of the cauteries becomes triangular.
Et elonga inter utraque ut non coniungantur, quando facient pus.	 And extend between both so that they do not join together, when it causes pus.
Et sit profunditas cauterii quantitas duarum tertiarum grossitudinis cutis.	 And let the depth of the cautery be the thickness of two thirds of the skin.
Et sit figura cauteriorum secundum hanc formam sine additione: et si uis cauteriza cauterio magno in medio stomachi secundum hanc formam: et sit cauterium quo fit hoc cauterium unum secundum figuram circuli secundum hanc formam.	 And let the figure of the cauteries be in this shape without addition: and if you wish, cauterize with a large cautery in the middle of the stomach according to this shape: and let the cautery that makes this cautery be one according to the shape of a circle according to this shape.
Et cauterizatur stomachus punctando ei qui terretur ab hoc cauterio: et est, ut signes super stomachum punctum secundum quantitatem, quam uis cum encaustro: deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio puncti: deinde cura ipsum cum curatione, quae praecessit donec sanetur.	 And the stomach is cauterized by puncturing it with the person who is afraid of this cautery: and there are signs marked on the stomach according to the amount you wish with the encaustrum: then cauterize itself with the cautery for the puncture: then care for it with the cure that preceded until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Epar frigidum.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing Epar (cold iron).
Caput XXIX.	 Chapter XXIX.
Quando accidit in Epate dolor ex frigiditate et humiditate, aut ex uentositate grossa, donec egrediatur a complexione sua naturali egressione superflua, et curatur infirmus, cum eo quod diximus, et non proficit in illo: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam, et signes cum encaustro tria cauteria secundum hanc figuram, et hanc quantitatem eandem super Epar inferius ab hypocundriis, ubi peruenit cubitus hominis: et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium secundum grossitudinem digiti: et sit cauterium secundum longitudinem corporis rectum: et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio multum.	 When there is pain in the liver due to coldness and dampness, or from large flatulence, until it exits from its natural exit of superfluous matter and the sick person recovers with what we have said and does not improve in that: then it is necessary that the sick person lies down on his neck, and marks with encaustrum three cauteries according to this shape, and the same size below Epar where the arm length reaches: and let the space between every cautery be the thickness of a finger: and let the cautery be according to the length of the body straight: and do not press your hand much with the cautery.
Et sit quantitas eius quod aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, quantitas medietatis eius non additum: et sit infirmus stans super pedes suos.	 And let the size of what is burned be according to the thickness of the skin, without addition: and let the sick person stand on his feet.
Si autem non est stans, tunc sit iacens, qui iam extendit crura sua, et eleuauit brachia sua.	 If it is not standing, then let it lie, which already extends its legs, and raises its arms.
Haec est forma cauterii.	 This is the form of cauterization.
Et tibi quidem possibile est, ut cauterizes ista cauteria cum cauterio cultellari, quando tecum est subtilitas et prudentia in arte.	 And indeed it is possible for you to perform this cauterization with a small knife cautery when subtlety and wisdom are present with you in the art.
Et custodi te, ut non ultime procedas in cauterizatione, et aduratur spissitudo cutis totius, quare aduratur corpus totum, et perueniat ad intestina: quoniam cutis illic est subtilis, scias ergo illud.	 And beware that you do not overly proceed in cauterization so that the thickness of the skin is burned throughout, wherefore the body is burned entirely and reaches the bowels; because the skin there is delicate, know this.
¶ De modo cauterizandi apostemata Epatis.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing liver abscesses.
Caput XXX.	 Head thirty.
Quando accidit exitura, et uis scire, si illud apostema est in carne Epatis, aut in tunica eius: tunc si est in carne Epatis, inuadit infirmum dolor, et grauitas absque acuitate: et si est in tunica Epatis, cum dolore est acuitas uehemens: et uides iam, quia fatigauit medicos eius curatio.	 When it happens that there is a discharge, and you want to know if the abscess is in the flesh of the liver or its membrane: then if it is in the flesh of the liver, there comes a mild pain and heaviness without sharpness; and if it is in the membrane of the liver, with intense pain there is a severe sharpness; and you see now that the treatment of this person has exhausted the doctors.
Oportet ergo ut resupinet infirmus super ceruicem suam.	 Therefore the sick man should lie on his neck.
Deinde figura locum apostematis cum encaustro: deinde ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	 Then shape the place of the abscess with a brazier; then light the cautery that resembles a rod.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its form.
Et cauteriza cum eo cauterium unum, donec comburatur cutis tota, et perueniat ad siphac, donec egrediatur sanies tota: deinde cura ipsum curatione exiturarum, donec sanetur.	 And cauterize it with a single cautery until the skin is burned entirely and reaches the membrane, until all pus comes out; then treat the person by means of treatment for discharges, until he is healed.
Et non oportet ut hac cauterii specie utatur, nisi cuius studium in arte medicinae prolongatur: et per cuius manus concurrunt aegritudines istae cum experimento aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super huiusmodi operationem.	 And it is not necessary to use this cauterization method, unless the zeal for the study of medicine prolongs one's life; and when these illnesses converge in one person with experience on occasion: then let him dare to perform such an operation.
At uero dimittere ipsam, apud me est melius.	 But rather to abandon it, is better in my opinion.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Pleuresi.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing pleurisy.
Caput XXXI.	 Head, Chapter XXXI.
Dixerunt antiqui, cauterium cum radicibus aristolochiae ad Pleuresim frigidam secundum hunc modum.	 The ancients said, cautery with the roots of Aristolochia for cold pleurisy according to this method.
Et est, ut recipias ex radicibus aristolochiae siccae longae, radicem unam longiorem, quae ex ea inuenitur, et sit sicut grossitudo digiti.	 And it is, that you receive from the dry roots of Aristolochia (long ones), one longer root which is found among them, and let it be as thick as a finger.
Deinde submerge eam in oleo: et accende ipsam in igne.	 Then immerse it in oil, and light it on fire.
Deinde cauteriza cauterio uno in eo quod est inter continuationem furculae cum collo, et duobus cauteriis paruis sub guidezi parum decliuibus ad partem, quae est sub barba.	 Then cauterize with one cautionery where it is between the neck of the collarbone and the neck, and with two small cauteries below in the hollow areas near the area that is under the beard.
Et duobus cauteriis etiam in eo, quod est inter costam quintam et sextam decliuibus ad posteriora parumper: et cauterio alio in medio pectoris, et alio supra stomachum.	 And with two small cauteries also where it is between the fifth and sixth ribs on the sides a little towards the back, and with one cautionery in the middle of the chest, and another above the stomach.
Et tribus cauteriis a posterioribus: uno in eo quod est inter duas spatulas: et duobus cauteriis a duobus lateribus pectoris, inferius cauterio quod est inter duas spatulas.	 And with three small cauteries from the back: one where it is between the scapulas (shoulder blades), and two from the sides of the chest, below, one where it is between the scapulas.
Et non oportet ut comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit in manifesto cutis odorando.	 And you should not press your hand with the cautionery, rather it should be in open air to smell the skin.
Et iam dixerunt quidam antiqui, quod ex hominibus sunt qui utuntur cauterio ex ferro simili radio: et igniunt, et intus mittunt ipsum in eo quod est inter costas, donec perueniatur cum eo ad ipsum apostema, et egrediatur sanies: sicut diximus in apostemate Epatis.	 And some of the ancients have said that there are men who use a cautery made of iron similar to a ray (probably a reference to a tool called radium), and heat it, and put it inside where it is between the ribs until they reach the abscess with it, and the pus comes out; as we have said in the abscess of the liver.
Sed in hac perforatione cum cauterio est ex timore, quod aut moritur infirmus statim, aut accidit in loco fistula, cui non est sanatio.	 But in this perforation with cautery, there is fear that either the sick person dies immediately, or a fistula occurs at the site, which does not heal.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Splenem Caput XXXII.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing the spleen, XXXII.
Quando tu curas aegritudinem splenis, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua, tunc cauterium in ea est secundum tres modos, qui omnes sunt recti.	 When you treat the illness of the spleen, as we have said in the treatment of diseases, and your treatment does not help, then there is a need for cautery on it according to three methods, which are all correct.
Quorum unus est, ut facias tria cauteria, aut quatuor lineando secundum longitudinem splenis secundum figuram cauteriorum Epatis, quorum praecessit figura.	 One (method) is to make three or four cauteries, by drawing them along the length of the spleen according to the shape of Epatis' cauterizations, whose preceding figure it is.
Et sit inter omne cauterium quantitas grossitudinis digiti, aut plus parum.	 And let each cautery be of thickness equal to that of a finger, or more or less.
Et sit modus cauterii, quem diximus in cauterio epatis aequaliter.	 Let the method of cauterizing, which we mentioned in the cauterization of the liver, be done equally.
Et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio: et sit infirmus resupinus super dorsum suum.	 And do not press your hand with the cautery; let the patient be weak and lying on his back.
Et modus alius de cauterizatione est: ut ignias cauterium habens duo uerua, quod diximus in capitulo dislocationis humeri: et eleua cutem, quae est in directo splenis, ubi peruenit cubitus infirmi sinister: et sit eleuatio tua qua eleuas cutem secundum latitudinem corporis, ut cadant cauteria secundum longitudinem corporis.	 Another method of cauterization is: holding the cautery with two openings, as we said in the chapter on dislocation of the shoulder; and peel off the skin that is directly over the spleen, where the elbow of the weak left arm comes to; and your peeling should be in the width of the body, so that the cauteries fall along the length of the body.
Deinde intromitte duo uerua ignita ualde, donec cum eis penetres cutem a parte altera: deinde extrahe cauterium: fiunt ergo cauteria quatuor.	 Then insert two openings with very hot fire until it penetrates the skin from the other side; then remove the cautery; thus there are four cauteries.
Et si uis cauteriza cum cauterio alio habente tria uerua.	 And if you wish to cauterize using a cautery with three openings.
Deinde cura cauterium postquam dimittis ipsum emittere pus diebus multis: est enim magis conferens quamque reliqua quae praecesserunt ex curatione.	 Then take care of the cautery after you release it, let it discharge pus for many days; for it is more effective than the rest that preceded in treatment.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Hydropisi.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in dropsy.
Caput XXXIII.	 Chapter XXXIII.
Cauterium non cadit in Hydropisi, nisi ascliti proprie.	 The cautery does not fall in dropsy unless it is properly applied.
Quando tu curas Hydropicum cum modis curationis, quos diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, et cauterio uno super stomachum, et cauterio alio super epar, et cauterio super splenem, et cauteriis duobus post dorsum inter spondiles, et uno in directo pectoris, et alio in directo stomachi: et sit quantitas profunditatis cauterii propinqua spissitudini cutis.	 When you treat a dropsy with the methods of treatment that we have mentioned in the division, and the treatment is not effective, then it is necessary to cauterize it with four cauteries around the navel, one on the stomach, another on the liver, another on the spleen, two behind the vertebrae, and one on the breastbone, and another on the stomach; and let the depth of the cautery be nearly equal to the thickness of the skin.
Deinde dimitte cauterium apertum, ut emittat pus tempore longo.	 Then let the open cautery emit pus for a long time.
Et non euacues infirmum a curatione post cauterium cum eo: quod oportet ut aggregentur ei duae intentiones: et festinabit ad ipsum sanatio cum auxilio Dei.	 And do not evacuate the weak patient from treatment after cauterization with it: this should be done so that two intentions are gathered to him: and healing will hasten towards it with God's help.
Forma uero cauterii cum quo cauterizatur uenter, sit clauilis: secundum quod praecessit forma eius: et illius cum quo cauterizatur dorsum, sit oliuaris secundum quod praecessit eius forma.	 The form of the cautery used to cauterize the abdomen should be a claw, according to its previous form; and the one with which the back is cauterized should be an oil jar, according to its previous form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Pedes, et Crura.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing feet and legs.
Caput XXXIIII.	 Chapter XXXIV.
Quando apostemantur in Hydropico, et replentur aqua citrina: oportet ut cauterizes super dorsum Pedis in nocrati, quae est inter auricularem et anularem: et eleua manum tuam cum cauterio, et non torqueas ipsum: deinde eleua manum tuam: et non iteres ipsum omnino.	 When they suffer from hydrops and are filled with citrus water, it is necessary to cauterize on the back of the foot in the nail area, which is between the earlobe and ankle; and hold the cautery with one hand and do not twist it; then remove your hand; and do not return to it at all.
Resudet enim aqua citrina, et sit cauterium secundum hanc formam.	 Citrus water will boil and the cautery should be of this shape.
Deinde fac super duo crura duo cauteria in omni crure, et fiat cauterium cum extremitate cultellari cauterii: et fiat cauterium secundum longitudinem cruris, unum sub genu, et alterum inferius eo, circiter medium cruris: et super omnem coxam cauteria duo: et dimitte cauterium apertum absque curatione tempore longo: ut resudet ex eo aliquod aquae: deinde cura ipsum cum reliquis quae diximus.	 Then make two cauteries for each leg, and let the cautery be with the tip of a scalpel-shaped cautery; and let the cautery be along the length of the leg, one below the knee, and the other below it, about halfway down the leg; and over the entire hip joint, place two cauteries; and leave the open cautery without treatment for a long time, so that some liquid boils out of it; then treat it as we have said.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in solutione Ventris.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in the resolution of the abdomen.
Caput XXXV.	 Chapter XXXV.
Quando est solutio uentris ex frigore et humiditatibus, donec debilitet uirtutes retentiuam et digestiuam, quae sunt in stomacho et intestinis: et curatur illud cum modis curationis, et non sanatur: et uides infirmum tolerantem cauterium exuberantis uirtutis, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio magno super stomachum suum, secundum quod praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi cum cauterio circuli, et quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici subtilibus, cum cauterio clauili subtili: et cauterio super alcatin supra alhosos magno, aut duobus cauteriis.	 When the abdomen is dissolved by cold and humidity until the retentive and digestive powers in the stomach and intestines weaken; and it is treated with methods of treatment but does not heal; and you see a weak person tolerating an excessively hot cautery, then cauterize it with a large cautery over its own stomach, according to the previous method of cauterizing the stomach with a ring-shaped cautery, and four subtle cauteries around the navel, with a thin claw-shaped cautery; and with a large cautery over the alcatin above the hips or with two cauteries.
Et si uides humiditates exuberantes, et infirmum tolerantem illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio super pectinem, et cauterio super omne ilium: et fortasse addes duo cauteria parua super stomachum prope magnum.	And if you see excessive moisture and the weak enduring it, then cauterize him with a cautery on his head and with a cautery over all of his back; and perhaps you will add two small cauteries near the stomach.
Est enim curatio proficiens, cuius iuuamentum non errat.	 The treatment is progressing, whose benefit does not stray.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Hemorroidas.	 [Title] On the method of cauterizing hemorrhoids.
Caput XXXVI.	 Chapter 36.
Quando in ano sunt Hemorroides antiquae multae, aut una, et sunt ex humoribus grossis, frigidis, aut humiditatibus corruptis, et curantur cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: tunc cauteriza tribus cauteriis super inferiorem spondilem dorsi sub almeidati parumper triangulatim, et cauterio sub umbilico quasi duobus digitis.	 When there are many old hemorrhoids in the anus, or one, and they are thick, cold, or corrupted by excessive moisture, and they are treated as we have said in the division, but the treatment does not help: then cauterize with three cauteries on the lower part of the back of the pelvis below the almuecate, triangularly, and with a cautery beneath the navel about two fingers.
Et si cogitas, quod stomachus eius infrigidatus sit, et cibus eius non digeratur, et faciem eius uides apostemari, tunc cauteriza eum super stomachum cauterio magno, secundum quod praecessit: et cauterio super Epar eius, et alio super Splenem ipsius, cum cauterio clauili: et dimitte cauterium apertum tempore aliquo: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 And if you think that his stomach is cold and food is not digested in him, and you see that his face is discolored, then cauterize him on the stomach with a large cautery as before; and with a cautery on his liver and another on his spleen, with a cautery at the clavicle; and leave the open cautery for some time; then care for him until he is cured.
¶ De modo cauterizandi althelul post abscisionem eorum.	 [Title] On the method of cauterizing an ulcer after its removal.
Caput XXXVII.	 Chapter 37.
Quando tu abscindis althelul, tunc ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	 When you amputate a toe (or digit), then heat the cautery similar to a rod.
Deinde intromittite ipsum ignitum in ipsum althelul abscisum: et ultima manum tuam, donec perueniat cauterium ad orificium uenae, ex qua currit sanguis: fac illud semel, aut bis.	 Then insert the heated (hot) instrument into the amputated toe (digit); and hold your hand until the cautery reaches the opening of the vein from which blood flows; do this once or twice.
Si ergo althelul fuerint multa, tunc cauteriza unumquodque cauterio secundum quod narrauimus.	 If there are many toes (digits) to be amputated, then cauterize each one with the cautery as we have described.
Deinde cura ea, cum eo quod confert eis ex unguentis, donec sanentur.	 Then care for them with the substance that you apply to them until they heal.
Et si cauterizas eum cauterio magno super alcatin, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	 And if you cauterize it with a large cautery on the boil, it is more beneficial for healing.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Fistulam in ano.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing an anal fistula.
Caput XXXVIII.	 Chapter 38.
Quando non obedit infirmus sectioni et operi quod narrauimus in loco suo, et terretur ab illo, fortasse sanatur cum cauterio.	 When the sick person does not obey the cutting and operation that we have described in its place, and is afraid of it, perhaps he will heal with cautery.
Cum ergo accidit alicui Fistula, et antiquatur, currit pus ex ea, et humiditates corruptae.	 If an anal fistula arises and becomes inflamed, pus flows from it, and the surrounding tissues become corrupted (rotten).
Dignius ergo quod oportet est, ut probes eam cum tenta subtili.	 Therefore, as is fitting, it should be examined with a probe of fine thread.
Deinde cognosce quantitatem profunditatis eius cum tenta.	 Then, recognize the depth of it with the probe.
Deinde ignias cauterium, quod est simile radio.	 Then heat the cautery which is similar to a rod.
Deinde intromit te ipsum ignitum in ipsam Fistulam et quantitatem in qua intrauit clauus.	 Then insert the heated instrument into the fistula up to the depth of the probe (clamp).
Et itera super eam cauterium, donec comburantur illa omnia corpora corrupta, semel, aut bis, aut ter, secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	 And repeatedly cauterize over it until all the corrupted tissues are burned away, once, twice, or three times, according to your need.
Et custodi te ab adustione nerui, si est illic, aut uenae magnae: aut si Fistula uadit ad corpus uesicae, aut ad corpus intestini, tunc custodi te ab istis locis omnibus.	 And be careful not to burn the nerve or large vein if it is there; or if the fistula leads to the bladder or the intestine, then be cautious in these areas.
Et non facias illud, nisi quando fistula est in loco carnoso: et cogitas, quia non est penetrans.	 Do not do this unless when the fistula is in a fleshy area; and reflect that it does not penetrate (pass through).
Deinde cura locum usquequo sanetur.	 Then take care of the place until it heals.
Si autem sigillatur locus, et abscinduntur ab eo materiae, et remanet sic tempore longo: tunc scias, quia iam sanatus est integre.	 If (the wound) is sealed and the matter within it is removed, and it remains in this state for a long time, then you will know that it has healed completely.
Et si non abscindunt ab eo materiae, tunc scias quia est penetrans, aut in profundo eius est os corruptum, aut quasi illud ex illis: quorum rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	 If the matter is not removed from it, then you will know that it is penetrating, or that the bone within it is rotten, or as if from one of those (things) whose memory comes to mind in its place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Renes.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing kidneys.
Caput XXXIX.	 Chapter XXXIX.
Quando accidit in Renibus dolor ex frigore, aut ex uentositate grossa, et minuitur propter illud coius infirmi, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum super almethenem super ipsos renes, cauterio super omnem renem cum cauterio clauili, cuius praecessit rememoratio.	 When pain occurs in the kidneys from cold or gross wind, and it weakens the body because of that, then it is necessary to cauterize it on top of the almethenem over both kidneys, with a cautery over the entire kidney with a claw-like cautery, whose precedent has been remembered.
Et fortasse cauterizamus ipsum secundo in ipso almeidatu.	 Perhaps we should cauterize it again in the same almeidatum.
Quare uenient tria lineata.	 Therefore, three lines will come.
Ergo erunt magis ultima in iuuamento.	 Hence they will be more beneficial at the end.
¶ De modo cauteritzandi Vesicam.	 Chapter on the mode of cauterizing the Bladder.
Caput XL.	 Chapter XL:
Quando accidunt in Vesica debilitas, et mollificatio a frigo re et humiditatibus, donec non retineat infirmus urinam, tunc cauteriza ipsum in inferiori parte suminis super Vesicam, ubi incipiunt pili pectinis, et cauterio a dextra suminis, et alio a sinistra illius: et sit longitudo illius cauterizationis lateris secundum quantitatem nodi pollicis: et cauteriza ipsum cauterio inferiori dorsi, aut duobus cauteriis, si indiges illo: et sit secundum quod praecessit cauterium clauile.	 When weakness and softening occur in the Bladder due to coldness and moisture, so that the sick person cannot retain urine, then cauterize it at its lower part on the anus above the Bladder, where the pubic hairs begin, and cauterize from the right anus, and another one from the left of it: and let the length of this cauterization be according to the size of a thumb knuckle: and cauterize it with a lower back cautery, or two cauteries, if necessary: and let it be as deep as the previous cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Matricem.	 When weakness and softening occur in the Womb due to coldness and moisture, so that the sick person cannot retain seed, then cauterize
Caput XLI.	 On Cauterizing the Uterus. In this Chapter,
Quando accidunt in Matrice frigus et humiditates, et prohibetur per illud ab impregnatione, et corrumpuntur menstrua eius, et tardatur prouocatio eorum, et accidit ei apud aduentum eorum dolor, tunc oportet ut cauterizetur tribus cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, sicut diximus in cauterizatione uesicae, et cauterio super alcatim inferius dorso, aut duobus cauteriis: et sit cauterium clauile.	 When coldness and moisture occur in the Uterus, and it is prevented from conception, and its menstruation is corrupted, and their provocation is delayed, and pain occurs near the time of their arrival, then it is necessary to be cauterized with three cauteries around the navel, as we said in the cauterization of the Bladder, and a cautery below the navel on the back, or with two cauteries: and let the cautery be deep.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Ancham in dislocatione.	 On Cauterizing the Anus in Dislocation. In this Chapter,
Caput XLII.	 When the anus is displaced from its place, then it should be reduced
Quando effunduntur humiditates mucosae ad pixidem Anchae, et fiunt caussa exitus eius a loco suo: et signum illius est, quod prolongatur crus super alterum, quando comparantur adinuicem: et inuenitur locus dislocationis in eo uacuus.	 and when the secretions of the mucous membrane flow towards the anus, and this causes its expulsion from its place, there is a sign that this has happened because the leg is prolonged above the other when they are put together: and a hollow is found in this displacement.
Oportet ergo ut cauterizes infirmum super pixidem Anchae ipsius cauterio simili circulo: postquam tu signas cum encaustro in circumitu pixidis, sicut reuoluitur: et ut cadat ipsa pixis in medio circuli.	 Therefore it is necessary to cauterize the sick person over the anus of this with a similar cautery in a circle around the anus: after you mark it with enkaustre around the anus, as it has been described: and let the anus fall into the center of the circle.
Et sit cauterium cuius forma praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi.	 And let the cautery be of the shape that precedes in the cauterization of the stomach.
Quod si tibi non est praesens hoc cauterium, tunc cauteriza ipsum tribus cauteriis, cum cauterio oliuari magno: et fiat cauterio profunditas secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis totius.	 If this cautery is not present to you, then cauterize it with three cauteries, together with a large oily cautery: and let the depth of the cautery be according to the thickness of the skin in total.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then take care of it until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Sciatica.	 On the method of cauterization for Sciatica.
Caput XLIII.	 Chapter XLIII.
Quando accidit dolor in pixide anchae, et sunt caussa illius frigus et humiditates: et curatur infirmus cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, et antiquatur illud: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum ab humoribus grossis cum pillulis foetidis, aut cum pillulis artificialibus, et similibus.	 When pain occurs in the ankle joint and its cause is coldness and moistness: and the sick person is treated as we said in division, but the treatment does not help, and it deteriorates: then it is necessary that you release the sick person from thick humors with fetid pills or with artificial pills and similar ones.
Deinde cauteriza eum.	 Then cauterize him.
Et modus cauterii in ea est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum medicinis adurentibus, aut cauterium cum igne.	 And the method of cauterization is done in two ways: either with cautery using medicaments or with fire.
Cauterium cum igne, est secundum multos modos.	 Cauterium cum medicinis adurentibus, est sic faciendum: Preparatur vas calidum et purgatur ab humore. Et in e
Quorum unus est, ut cauterizes super pixidem anchae ipsius tribus cauteriis triangulatis, secundum hanc formam.	 One method is to cauterize on the joint of the ankle with three triangular cauteries in this manner:
Et fac eis profunditatem bonam, uel malam.	 And make it a good or bad depth for them.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium quantitatis grossitudinis digiti: sitque cauterium oliuare.	 And let the space be which is between every cautery of this size, that of a finger's thickness: and let the cautery be oil-soaked.
Quandoque autem fit cauterium in medio super caput anchae ipsius.	 Sometimes the cautery is done in the middle on top of the ankle joint itself.
Quare sunt quatuor cauteria.	 Why are there four cauteries?
Et si uis cauteriza cum circulo, cuius praecessit forma in cauterizatione dislocationis anchae, uno: ut sit circulus continens ancham totam.	 If you wish to cauterize with a circle that precedes the form of the ankle joint dislocation, it should be one: so that the circle contains the ankle joint completely.
Et combure spissitudinem cutis totius.	 And burn the thickness of the skin all around.
Iste est modus cauterii in Sciatica, quando dolor est adhaerens anchae ipsi, et non extenditur usque ad coxam et crus.	 This is the method of cauterization for sciatica, when the pain is adhering to the ankle itself and does not extend to the hip and leg.
Si autem extenditur usque ad coxam et crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis super coxam, super locum ad quem innuit illic infirmus, in quo est dolor, et cauterio tuo super cauillam quatuor digitis ad partem syluestrem parumper: et sit cauterium cultellare.	 If it extends to the hip and leg, then cauterize it with two cauteries on the hip, at the place where the sick person indicates, where the pain is, and with your cautery four fingers towards the outer part: and let the cautery be sharp-pointed.
Et sit profunditas cauterii secundum profunditatem spissitudinis cutis.	 And let the depth of the cautery be according to the thickness of the skin.
Quod si infirmus innuit quod dolor extenditur usque prope digitos pedis, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic ubi innuit cum cauterio puncti, tribus, aut quatuor, aut pluribus, si indiget illo.	 If the sick person indicates that the pain extends up to the toes of the foot, then cauterize it there where he indicates, with a cautery of points, three, or four, or more, if necessary.
Et si innuit dolorem esse sub genu uersus crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic cauterio uno cultellari.	 And if he indicates that the pain is turned towards the leg from the knee, then cauterize it there with a single knife-cautery.
Et caue tibi in omni cauterizatione tua, ut non ultimes cum cauterio ad hoc ut comburas neruum, aut arteriam magnam, et attrahas per illud super infirmum nocumentum malum, aut contractionem.	 And beware of yourself in all your cauterizations, so that you do not burn the nerve or great artery with the cautery, and attract harm or contraction upon the sick person through it.
Et ego quidem iam uidi unum et alium, ex eis qui cauterizauerunt supra cauillam, et ultimauerunt in cauterizatione, et inflatum est crus, donec tumor consecutus est pedem, et perforatus est totus, et corruptus est totus pes: deinde accidit solutio uentris, et mors post illud.	 And I myself have already seen one and another who cauterized above the heel and exceeded in their cauterization, and the leg became swollen until the tumor reached the foot, and it was perforated all over, and the entire foot was rotten; then there followed a rupture of the abdomen, and death after that.
Quod si dolor est in duabus partibus simul, cauteriza utramque secundum hunc modum.	 If the pain is in two places at once, cauterize each one according to this method.
Et sapientes quidam dixerunt in cauterizatione anchae, cuius cauterii iste est modus.	 And some wise men have said about cauterizing the anus, that this is the method of the cautery.
Fac simile samio ex ferro, cuius diametrus sit medietas palmi: et sit apud orificium suum secundum grossitudinem nuclei dactyli, aut minus parumper: et intra illud samium sit samium tertium.	 Make a brazier similar to a thimble, whose diameter is half the width of the palm; and it should be placed at the opening according to its size, namely the thickness of the tip of a finger or less; and inside this brazier should be another smaller brazier.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne samium per quantitatem nodi pollicis: et sint samia aperta a duabus partibus: et sit altitudo eorum quasi nodus, aut duo nodi: et fac eis manubrium ex ferro decenter aptatum in samiis.	 And let the space between all the braziers be the size of a grape; and let the braziers have openings on two sides; and let their height be like that of a knuckle, or two knuckles; and make handles for them from iron suitably attached to the braziers.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its form.
Deinde igniatur in igne, donec rubeat, et proiiciat scintillas: deinde ponatur super pixidem anchae infirmo accubitato super latus sanum.	 Then it is heated in the fire until it glows and sparks; then it should be placed on a brazier near the sick anus, who lies on his healthy side.
Cauteriza ergo eum tribus cauteriis rotundis in uice una.	 Cauterize him therefore with three round caustics at once.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	 Then release him for three days.
Postea emplastra cum butyro: et dimitte uulnus apertum diebus multis.	 Afterwards pack it with butter; and leave the open wound for many days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then treat him with an ointment until he is healed.
Inquit Albucasis, hac specie cauterii o filii, parum usi sumus, propter terrorem aspectus eius: et propterea, quod paucos inuenimus qui expectent super ipsum.	 Says Albucasis to his sons, we have too little used the method of cauterization with this appearance, due to fear of its aspect; and therefore, because few are found who await him.
Verumtamen est ex bonis cauteriis ei qui suffert, et inuenit cum eo locum eius.	 Nevertheless, it is one of the good caustics for him that endures it, and finds a place for it.
Cauterium autem cum medicinis adurentibus est, ut tu facias duo samia habentia perforatam armillam, in quam descendit cardo portae eius ex aere, aut ferro, longitudo parietis: quorum in altitudinem eorum sint duo nodi, aut quasi ipsi.	 However, cautery with acting medicines is to be done thus by you: take two samia having a perforated armillary, into which descends the pin of his door from bronze or iron, the length of the wall; whose height should be two knots, or as if themselves.
Et sit spacium quod est inter utraque quantitas grossitudinis digiti, et sint aperta inferius et superius: et sit quod contineant se adinuicem, secundum hanc formam.	 And let the space that is between the two be of the size of the thickness of a finger, and be open below and above; and let it hold each other in place according to this shape.
Deinde depone eam super pixidem anchae, infirmo iacente super latus sanum.	 Then lay it on a pot-ash anchor, with the weak one lying upon the healthy side.
Et comprime manum tuam super pixidem anchae multum.	 And press your hand very much upon the pot-ash anchor.
Deinde funde inter duos circulos ex aqua calida, quae sit calefacta cum igne parumper, et tene eam quantitate horae temporalis: et toleret infirmus mordicationem eius, et ipsius adustionem, nam ipse inuenit mordicationem sicut ignis, donec quiescat mordicatio.	 Then pour between two circles of warm water, which is heated a little with fire and hold it for the length of an hour; and let the weak one endure the biting of it, and his burning, for he finds the biting as fire, until the biting stops.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum instrumento, et absterge aquam calidam ab ancha tota cum aqua dulci: deinde dimitte illud tribus diebus.	 Then wash your hand with an instrument, and remove warm water from the entire pot-ash anchor with sweet water; then release it for three days.
Et pone super illud butyrum, donec remoueatur nigredo adustionis: et dimitte illud diebus aliquot, et curret ex eo pus.	 And place butter over it until the blackness of burning is removed; and release it for some days, and let pus run out from it.
Est enim ultimum in iuuamento.	 It is indeed the final help [remedy] [in a medical treatment].
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	 Then treat it with ointments until it heals.
Quod si extendatur dolor usque ad coxam, aut crus: fac ei statuam in eo quod continet aquam, secundum quod fecisti in ancha aequaliter.	 If the pain spreads to the hip or leg: make a socket in it that contains water, as you did equally in the ankle.
Et iste est modus aquae calidae: et ego iam scripsi eam in tractatu rectificationis medicinarum.	 And this is the method of hot water: and I have already written it in the treatise on the correction of drugs.
Sume alcali, et calcis non extinctae amborum ana partem unam: tere utraque, et pone ea in ollam nouam, cuius inferior pars sit perforata foramine uno paruo, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum radius: et pone sub fundo ollae ollam aliam uitreatam: et proiice super alcali et calcem ex aqua dulci, quod submergat utraque per digitum: post quam tu comprimas ea manu tua compressione bona: et dimite ollam, donec descendat aqua acuta inferiori parte ollae uitreatae.	 Take equal parts of alkali and unburnt lime, grind each one separately, put them in a new pot whose lower part is perforated by a small hole, according to the quantity that will enter [the pot], namely the radius: put another unglazed pot beneath it: pour over the alkali and lime from sweet water, so that each submerges to the depth of a finger: after you have compressed them with your hand, let it stand until the sharp water comes out through the lower part of the unglazed pot.
Deinde aggrega illam aquam totam, et proiice eam super aliam calcem: et cola, donec renouetur.	 Then mix that water with another lime: and boil it until it returns.
Ipsa enim erit tunc fortis acuitatis ualde, quae administratur in multis operationibus medicinae, et in cauterizatione reliquorum membrorum.	 It will then be indeed very strong against sharpness, which is used in many medical procedures and in the cauterization of other parts [of the body].
Quoniam efficit operationem ignis ipsius.	 Since it performs the operation of fire itself.
Et ex medicinis sunt, cum quibus cauterizantur ancha, etiam sicut tesisie, et mel anacardi, et calx cum sapone, ita quod utraque sint permixta. ¶	 And from the drugs used in the cauterization of ankles, such as tetisie, honey from the nutmeg tree, lime with soap, so that each is mixed together. (The rest of the sentence is incomplete and cannot be translated accurately without additional context.)
Et Galenus quidem narrando retulit, cuiusdam uiri ex antiquis curationem, qua curatus est dolor anchae et uenae sciaticae: et magnificauit esse eius ualde.	 And Galenus himself, in his narrative, reported a cure for the pain of an ankle and sciatic vein, which he highly praised [as very effective].
Et dixit, quia non indiguit alia curatione, et quia sanatus est ex uice una, donec retulit, quia ipse fortasse intrauit balneum delatus, et exiuit ex eo iam sanus.	 And he said that it did not require any other cure, and that it was cured with just one application, as long as [the patient] himself probably entered a bath, and came out healthy from there.
Et est, ut accipiatur ex seitaragi uiridi: et si non inuenitur uiride, sumatur siccum, recens: et teratur multum cum aliquanto adipe, et ponatur super ancham, ubi est dolor, aut crus, aut in coxa: et ligetur, et dimittatur quantitate trium horarum, aut per quantitatem quod sentiat infirmus sedationem adustionis.	 And it is to be taken from green seitaragia: and if it is not found as green, take dry and recent one; and grind much with some fat, and place on the sore, whether it is on the leg or in the hip: and tie it, and leave for a quantity of three hours, or until it feels a weak sensation of heating.
Deinde intromitte eum in balneum.	 Then insert it into the bath.
Cum ergo roridum fit corpus eius, intromitte ipsum in solium.	 When its body becomes warm, insert it into the sun.
Nam dolor recedit, et sanatur.	 For pain recedes, and it heals.
Et scias, quia non oportet ut utatur aliquis cauterio cum istis medicinis, nisi post euacuationem corporis.	 And know that no one should use cautery with these medications unless after evacuation of the body.
Et Dioscorides qui dem dixit, quod stercus caprarum, quando cum eo cauterizatur uena sciatica, confert ei: et fit cauterium secundum hunc modum.	 And Dioscorides who said that goat dung, when it is burned with sciatic vein, gives it: and the cautery is made according to this method.
Sumatur lana, et imbibatur oleo antiquo, et ponatur super locum profundum, qui est inter pollicem pedis, et inter focile, et est propinquior focili.	 Take wool and soak it in old oil, and place it on the deep place that is between the toe of the foot and the heel, and closer to the heel.
Deinde accipe stercus caprarum siccum, et inflamma ipsum in igne, donec fiat carbo.	 Then take dry goat dung, ignite it in fire until it becomes charcoal.
Deinde pone ipsum super lanam, et dimitte ipsum, donec extinguatur.	 Then place it on the wool and leave it until it is extinguished.
Deinde itera illud.	 Then repeat that procedure.
Non cesses ergo facere illud, usquequo perueniat sensus super mediatione usque ad ancham, et quiescat dolor.	 Do not stop doing that until the sensation reaches the sore and the pain ceases.
Et iste modus cauterii nominatur cauterium Vaccinum.	 And this method of cautery is called "cauterium Vaccinum".
¶ De cauterizatione doloris Dorsi.	 [Section heading] On the cauterization of back pain.
Caput XLIIII.	 Chapter XLIV.
Quandoque accidit dolor in Dorso ex caussis multis, aut a casu, aut a percussione, aut euacuatione superflua, et illis similibus, ex infusione materiei frigidae, et humidae: et cauterium quidem non cadit, nisi in hac specie sola, quae fit ex infusione materiei frigidae.	 Sometimes pain occurs in the back due to many causes, either from a fall, strike, excessive evacuation, or similar things, due to the influx of cold and moist matter. And cautionery does not apply except in this single case, which is made by the influx of cold matter.
Oportet ergo post euacuationem infirmi cum pillulis foetidis, et eis similibus, ut fiant super Dorsum, ubi est dolor, tres lineae secundum latitudinem almeidati ipsius, postquam signas cum encaustro in omni linea quinque cauteria, aut plura secundum quantitatem quae uenit ex tolerantia infirmi uirtute eius: et fiat cauterizatio cum cauteriopuncti.	 Therefore, after the evacuation of the sick person with fetid pills and similar ones, three lines should be made on the back where there is pain, according to the width of the palm itself, after marking them with encaustic in every line with five cauteries or more according to the amount that comes from the strength of the sick person. And the cauterization should be done with cauteriopuncti.
Et si uis, cauteriza tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor, cum cauterio clauili mediali, secundum hanc formam.	 And if you wish, cauterize with three or four cauteries along with a median claw-shaped cautery in this manner.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in incaeptine Gibbositatis.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in hump-like growths.
Caput XLV.	 Chapter 45.
Multotiens accidit haec aegritudo infantibus paruis.	 This illness often occurs in small children many times.
Et signum incaeptionis eius in pueris est: quod accidit super eum strictura in anhelitu apud eleuationem, et motum: et inuenis in ultima spondilium Dorsi et nodorum eius, quod iam incaepit eminere super reliquos spondiles.	 And the sign of its incipient growth in children is that it occurs upon them during stridor at elevation, and movement: and you find at the bottom of the spine and the nodes of this that it has begun to protrude above the other spines.
Cum ergo uides illud, et uis facere illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio quod sit circulus secundum hanc formam.	 When you see that and wish to make it, then cauterize it with a round-shaped cautery in this manner.
Et capiat cauterium super omnem partem spondilis aequaliter: et si uis cauteriza in circumitu spondilis cum cauterio puncti duas lineas, aut tres: et sint puncta propinqua adinuicem.	 And take the cautery over the entire spine equally: and if you wish to cauterize around the spine with a puncture-shaped cautery, make two lines or three; and let the punctures be close to each other.
Deinde cura locum, donec sanetur cum eo quod diximus.	 Then take care of the place until it heals as we have said.
Et caue, ne administres cauterium in gibbositate, quae fit in spasmo nerui.	 And beware not to administer cautionery in a hump-like growth that is caused by a spasm of the nerve.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Podagra, et doloribus iuncturarum.	 On the method of cauterizing in gout, and the pains of joints.
Caput XLVI.	 De modo cauterizandi in podagra et doloribus artic
Quando dolores iuncturarum sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, quae effunduntur ad cuiuslibet membra corporis, tunc quando accidunt dolores in pedibus, de consuetudine medicorum est, ut nominent illud Podagram proprie.	 When the pains of joints are due to cold and moist humors which flow into any part of the body, then when such pains occur in the feet, it is proper for physicians to call it gout (Podagra).
Cum ergo curatur Podagra frigidae caussae cum modis curationis, et non remouentur dolores, tune cauterium remouet eos.	 Since gout caused by cold is treated with various methods of treatment and the pains are not removed, then cautery removes them.
Et est, ut cauterizes eum post euacuationem in circumitu iuncturae pedum, cauteriis multis: et sit cauterium Oliuare.	 And it is that one should cauterize it after evacuation around the joint of the foot, with many cauteries; and let the cautery be Oilburner.
Cuius haec est forma.	 This is its form.
Et si indiges ut punctes super faciem pedis, tunc fac cum cauterio puncti.	 And if you need to puncture the sole of the foot, then do it with a cautery point.
Quod si ascendunt dolores usque ad genua, aut reliquas iuncturas, et multotiens accidit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super omne genu tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor ab omni parte, cum hoc eodem cauterio Clauili.	 If the pains rise up to the knees or other joints and it frequently happens so, then cauterize it over the whole knee with three or four cauteries from all sides, using this same cautery called Clauile.
Si autem necessaria sunt tibi plura hoc cauterio, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	 If more than one cautery is required for you, then cauterize it.
Et non submergas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit circiter spissitudinem cutis tantum.	 And do not immerse your hand with the cautery, rather let it be about as thick as the skin.
Si autem ascendunt dolores ad genua, et dorsum: tunc administra quod diximus ex cauterio in capitulo suo.	 If the pains rise up to the knees and the back, then administer what was said in the chapter on it.
Quod si dolores sunt in manibus tantum, tunc puncta in circumitu focilium, sicut reuoluuntur duae lineae.	 If the pains are only in the hands, then puncture around the knuckles, as if two lines were turned over.
Si autem remanet ex doloribus in digitis, tunc puncta eos, super omnem nodum punctum, et super pectinem manus.	 If pain remains only in the fingers, then puncture them all, on every knuckle and on the back of the hand.
Si autem ascendunt dolores post dies ad cubitos, aut ad humeros, tunc cauteriza utrosque ab omni parte.	 If the pains rise up after days to the elbows or shoulders, then cauterize both from all sides.
Et non euacues infirmum ex regimine bono, ex recaeptione medicinarum.	 And do not evacuate the weak from good management, from receiving medications.
Nam si bonum fiat regimen, et euacuetur phlegma, sanabitur auxilio Dei cum isto cauterio.	 If good care is taken and phlegm is evacuated, it will be cured with God's help by means of this cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Rupturis.	 On the method of cauterization for ruptures.
Caput XLVII.	 Chapter Forty-Seven.
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, et descendit intestinum, aut zirbum ad testiculum, et est illud incipiens propinquum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo dimittere comestionem in die suo.	 When a rupture occurs in the groins and the intestine or the scrotum descends, and it is beginning nearby: then one should order the patient to abstain from food on his own day.
Et utatur ex lenientibus, quo descendat stercus a uentre suo.	 And let him use laxatives, so that he may expel feces from his belly.
Deinde sedeat inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et praecipe ei, ut teneat anhelitum suum, donec egrediatur, uel appareat zirbum, aut intestinum.	 Then let him sit on his back before you; and order him to hold his breath until the scrotum appears or the intestine does.
Deinde reduc ipsum digitis tuis, et signa cum encaustro sub Ruptura super os pectinis, cum signo cuius extremitas sit similis medietati circuli ad superiora corporis.	 Then reduce him with your fingers and mark the place of rupture on his chest with hot wax, using a sign whose end is similar to the diameter of half a circle above his body.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma, donec ueniat album, et proiiciat seintillas.	 Then heat the cautery of this shape until it becomes white and throw pieces of hot iron on it.
Deinde reduc intestinum, aut zirbum ad concauitatem suam.	 Then return the intestine or scrotum to its hollow.
Deinde ponat minister manum suam super locum, ut non exeat intestinum: et tu iam aperuisti inter crura infirmi, et posuisti sub eo puluinar, et seruiens alius super crura eius, et alius super pectus eius qui tenet manus.	 Then let the servant place his hand on the place, so that the intestine does not come out; and you have already opened between the legs of the patient, and you placed a stone under him, and another servant is on his thighs, and another on his chest who holds his hands.
Deinde depone cauterium super ipsum signum, manu tua cum cauterio stante recta.	 Then place the cautery on the mark, with your hand holding the cautery upright.
Et tene ipsum, donec cum eo consequaris os: aut itera cum eo uice alia, si non consecutus fueris cum eo in prima usque ad os.	 And hold him until you meet the bone with it; or use another place if you are not able to meet the bone with it until the bone.
Et prudenter obserua ab exitu intestini in hora cauterizationis tuae, ne comburas ipsum, et eueniat per illud super infirmum aut mors, aut malicia magna.	 And carefully observe the exit of the intestine at the hour of your cautery, so that you do not burn him and it comes over him, or he dies from it or suffers great harm.
Et scias, quod quando tu non consequeris cum cauterio os, non confert operatio tua.	 And know that when you do not meet the bone with the cautery, your operation is of no avail.
Et oportet ut sit cauterium infantium subtile, secundum mensuram eorum.	 And it must be a small, delicate cautery for children, according to their size.
Deinde cura cum reliquis unguentis, donec sanetur.	 Then treat with the remaining ointments until he is healed.
Et sit infirmus iacens super dorsum suum quadraginta diebus, donec sigilletur uulnus.	 The patient lies down for forty days until the wound is sealed.
Et oportet, ut ponas nutrimentum eius longitudine temporis curationis eius, quod leniat uentrem eius: ut non exeat intestinum apud conamen et egestionem.	 It is necessary that you place the nourishment for him according to the length of his treatment time, so as to soften his stomach; lest his intestines go out during attempts at evacuation and famine.
Deinde quando uult surgere post quadraginta dies, tunc administra ligamentum decenter factum, et teneat ipsum quadraginta diebus aliis.	 Then when he wishes to rise after forty days, then administer a well-made bandage and let him hold it for another forty days.
Et minoretur a labore, et repletione cibi et potus, et uocibus uehementibus.	 Let him be lessened in labor, and fullness of food and drink, and violent voices.
Nam quando utitur hoc regimine, ita sanatur sanatione integra.	 For when he uses this regime, thus is he cured with complete healing.
Et ego dicam curationem Rupturarum cum incisione in capitulo suo.	 And I will say the cure for hernias with an incision in its own chapter.
Quando autem Rupturae accidunt in reliquo uentre, et sunt incipientes, et uis ut non addantur, tunc cauteriza Rupturam eius cauterio rotundo secundum quantitatem eius: et sit illud quod aduritur ex tunc sicut tertia eius.	 When hernias occur in the rest of the abdomen and are beginning and they fear that they will increase, then cauterize the hernia with a round cautery according to its size; and let it be what is burned from that point on as one third of it.
Deinde cura ipsum, cum eo quod diximus: et non addetur.	 Then care for him as I have said; do not add to it.
Et iam dixerunt quidam primi: ut cauterizetur Ruptura cum cauterio triangulato, secundum hanc formam.	 And some of the first ones have said that the hernia should be cauterized with a triangular cautery in this shape.
Postquam signatur cum encaustro, et ponitur linea quae est per latitudinem in latere superiori Rupturae, et linea altera ad inferius.	 After it is signed with pitch and a line is placed that is across its width on the upper side of the hernia, and another line downwards.
Et depone manum tuam in medio cum cauterio clauili.	 And place your hand in the middle with the awl (clavius).
Sed cauterium primum est facilius et melius.	 But the first cautery is easier and better.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in doloribus propter casum, aut percussionem.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing for pain due to a blow or impact.
Caput XLVIII.	 Chapter XLVIII.
Quando accidit in quibusdam membris a casu, aut percussione dolor: et perseuerat ille dolor tempore longo, et non confert in eo curatio cum medicinis: tunc oportet ut cauterizetur cum cauterio Puncti.	 When pain occurs in some limbs due to a blow or impact; and the pain persists for a long time and there is no help with medications, then it is necessary that it be cauterized with the puncture cautery.
Et sit cauterium omnis membri cauterium secundum magnitudinem eius, et ipsius paruitatem, et debilitatem eius, et ipsius uirtutem, et locationem torsionis, et doloris ex eo.	 And let the cautery be for every member, according to its size and its smallness, and its weakness, and its strength, and its location of twisting, and the pain from it.
Si ergo sanatur ex cauterio primo, est bene.	 If he is cured by the first cautery, it is good.
Si non: tunc itera super ipsum cauterium.	 If not: then repeat the cautery upon him.
Quoniam de consuetudine horum dolorum est, ut permutentur ex membro ad illud quod appropinquat ei.	 Because it is customary for these pains to change from one member to another that is near it.
Quare oportet ut consequaris eos cum cauterio, donec sanetur infirmus.	 Therefore, you must follow them with the cautery until the sick man is cured.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lepra.	 Chapter on the mode of cauterizing in Leprosy.
Caput XLIX.	 Chapter XLIX.
Leprosi autem quandoque iuuantur cauterio iuuamento maximo.	 The leprous, however, are sometimes helped greatly by the cautery.
Et praecipue species Leprae, quae fit propter putrefactionem phlegmatis et melancholiae: cum ergo uis cauterizare ipsam considera.	 And particularly the species of leprosy which is caused by putrefaction of phlegm and melancholy: when you consider the need to cauterize it.
Si ergo Lepra est ineipiciens, et curasti eam cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non descendit, neque stat: et times super infirmum, quod comprehendat corruptio super totam complexionem eius: tunc cauteriza eum super caput quinque cauteriis: uno in medio capitis noto, et secundo inferius eo uersus frontem apud finem capillorum, et duobus super duo cornua, et uno posterius super nucea ceruicis.	 If the leprosy is incipient and you have treated it as we said in the division, and it does not decrease nor cease: beware of the sick man, lest corruption spread over his entire complexion: then cauterize him on the head with five cauteries: one in the middle of the head, known, and the second below it facing the forehead at the end of the hair, and two above the two horns, and one behind it over the nuchal bone of the neck.
Et ultima manum tuam cum cauterio parumper, donec imprimat in os impressionem paruam, et dislocentur ex eo cortices: ut alleuietur expiratio uaporum grossorum ex eo, et cauteriza cauterio etiam super ipsum splenem, secundum quod praecessit.	 And lay your hand with the cautery a little longer, until it makes an impression smaller than the palm in the bone, and the cortices will be displaced: so that the expiration of gross vapors from it may be alleviated, and cauterize the spleen also with the cautery according to what has preceded.
Sin autem Lepra iam sparsa est super infirmum, et apparet manifeste: tunc oportet ut cauterizes cum istis cauteriis, quae diximus in capite, et cauterio super extremitatem nasi, et duobus cauteriis super duas maxillas, et duobus cauteriis super spondiles colli, et sex super spondiles dorsi, et uno magno super alhahosos apud gran caudae et uno supra ipsum, in ipso almeidati: et duobus super anchas: scilicet super omnem ancham uno, et duobus super genua: uno super omne genu, et duobus super humeros, et duobus super cubitos, et duobus super teneritudines pectoris sui: et cauteriza ipsum super omnem iuncturam, ex iuncturis digitorum manuum suarum, et pedum suorum: et cauteriza super omnem calcaneum pedum suorum, et focilia manuum suarum.	 If the leprosy is already spread over the sick person and it is evident: then you must cauterize with these cauteries which we said in the head, and a cautery on the tip of the nose, and two cauteries on the two cheeks, and two cauteries on the spondyles of the neck, and six on the spondyles of the back, and one large one over the alhahosos near the gran caudae and one on it, in the almeidat: and two over the ankles: namely over every ankle with one, and two over the knees, and two over the shoulders, and two over the elbows, and two over the forearms, and two over the softnesses of the chest: and cauterize it over every joint of his fingers on both hands, and feet: and cauterize over all calcaneum of his feet, and focilia of his hands.
Et caue tibi a neruis qui sunt super postremum calcanei, ut non comburas eos.	 Beware that you do not burn the nerves which are on top of the last heel bone, so as not to burn them.
Et quandoque cauterizatur cauterio super os pectinis, et alio super os stomachi, et alio super epar.	 And sometimes it is cauterized with a cautery on the chin, and another time on the belly, and another time on the epigastrium.
Et scias, quod quanto plus addis cauterium, est magis iuuamentum, et magis conferens.	 And know that the more you add cautionary substances, the more beneficial it is, and the more conducive to success.
Et scias, quod infirmus non inuenit in cauterio dolorem, sicut inueniunt ipsum sani: propterea, quod corpus eius iam stupefactum est.	 And know that the sick do not feel pain in cautery, as the healthy do; therefore, because his body is already numb.
Et oportet ut sint cauteria ex magnitudine, et paruitate secundum membra et iuncturas: secundum quod praecessit ex speciebus ferramentorum.	 It is necessary that the cauteries be of suitable size and shape according to the members and joints; accordingly, they should be made from a particular type of iron.
Deinde cura cauterium ex farina herbi cum melle, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 Then care for the cautery with flour of herbs mixed with honey, and the rest of the treatment until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Stupore.	 Chapter on the method of cauterization in stupor (faint or delirium).
Caput L.	 Chapter L.
Quando stupet aliquod membrum, et curatur cum medicinis, et oleis, et emplastris, et non sanatur, tunc cauteriza ipsum membrum stupefactum cauteriis, secundum quod meretur magnitudo membri, aut paruitas eius.	 When any member becomes numb and is treated with medicines, oils, plasters, and yet does not heal, then the affected member should be cauterized with cauteries according to the size or condition of the member.
Et sit cauterium tuum intrans in spissitudinem cutis parumper.	 Let your cautery enter the thickness of the skin a little way.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then take care of it with an ointment until it heals.
Et quandoque cauterizatur ad quiddam stuporis, qui accidit manui, et pedi, in spondilibus dorsi apud exitum neruorum, qui mouent illud membrum: et remouetur stupor.	 Furthermore, when the cautery is applied to some numbness that happens in the hand and foot, in the joints of the back near the nerve exits that move that member, the numbness will be removed.
Verum non praesumat super illud, nisi qui est sapiens in anatomia membrorum, et egressione neruorum mouentium corpus.	 However, do not presume to act upon it unless he is wise in the knowledge of the structure of members and the exit of nerves moving the body.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Albaras.	 Chapter on Cauterization in Albaraz.
Caput LI.	 Title LXI.
Quando antiquatur Albaras, et non confert in eo aliquid ex ingeniis medicinae: tunc cauteriza super ipsam cauterio profundo parumper, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis, donec remoueatur albedo, et mutetur color eius.	 When Albaraz decays and does not offer any help from the art of medicine: then cauterize on top of it with a deep cautery a little way, according to the thickness of the skin until the whiteness disappears and the color changes.
Deinde cura ipsum cum farina herbi, et lentis cum oleo rosa, et foliis arnoglossae, et sanguine columbae, et sanguine hyrundinis: de unoquoque sit pars una: misceantur haec omnia, et liniantur super pannum, et adhaereant loco, donec sanetur.	 Then take care of it with a mixture of grain of wheat, lentils with rose oil, leaves of arnoglossa, blood of a dove, and blood of a frog: equal parts of each: mix all these together, soak them on cloth, and apply them to the place until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Cancro.	 Chapter on Cauterization for Cancer.
Caput LII.	 Title LXII.
Quando Cancer est incipiens, et uis ipsum sistere: tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio circuli in circuitu eius, sicuti reuoluitur.	 When cancer is beginning and you wish to stop it: then cauterize it with a circular cautery around its circumference, as is customary.
Sapientes autem dixerunt, ut cauterizetur cauterio ultimo in medio.	 Wise men have said, it should be cauterized with the last cautery in the middle.
Mihi autem non uidetur illud: quoniam timeo quod ulceretur: et ego iam uidi illud aliquotiens.	 But that does not seem right to me, for I fear it would cause an ulcer; and I have already seen that happen several times.
Et rectius est, ut cauterizetur in circumitu eius cum circulo, sicut diximus: aut cauteriis multis.	 It is rather right to cauterize around it with a circular cautery, as we have said; or with multiple cauteries.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Adubelati.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in Adubelati.
Caput LIII.	 Chapter XXXIII.
Quando aliquis habet Adubelati, et tardatur in maturatione, aut propter superfluitatem facientem eam, aut propter aetatem infirmi, quando est decrepitus pauci sanguinis, aut propter tempus, et uis festinare in maturatione Adubelati, tunc cauteriza in circumitu eius cum cauteriis paruis multis punctando.	 When someone has Adubelati and it slows in maturation due to an excess causing it or due to the weakness of old age, when it is very few in blood, or due to time and you wish to hasten the maturation of Adubelati, then cauterize around it with small multiple cauteries by puncturing.
Deinde dimitte eam.	 Then let it be released.
Nam ipsa festinabit cum maturatione.	 For itself it will hasten with maturation.
Si autem uis perforationem eius cum cauterio, tunc igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma.	 If you wish to perforate it with a cautery, then fire the cautery, whose form is this: (no further text provided)
Et depone ipsum in medio Adubelati, donec penetret cutem: et sit cauterium ab eo quod sequitur infirmus, ut alleuietur cursus puris.	 And place it in the middle of the Adubelati until it penetrates the skin; and let the cautery be weak, so that its course may be made pure.
Deinde cura ipsum donec sanetur.	 Then care for it until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in malo corrodente.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in a cancerous ulcer.
Caput LIIII.	 Chapter XXXIV.
Corrodens non est nisi corruptio in membro ambulans, et corrodit ipsum: sicut ignis comedit ligna sicca.	 Corrosion is only corruption walking in a limb and consumes it; just as fire consumes dry wood.
Si ergo uides corrodentem in loco qui toleret cauterium cum igne, tunc igni cauteria multa, clauilia parua et magna, secundum quod conueniet illi loco in quo est corrodens.	 If you see a corrosion in a place that can bear cautery with fire, then apply much cautery, small and large nails, according to what suits the place where the corrosion is located.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum ab omni parte donec eradices corruptionem totam, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid penitus.	 Then cauterize it from all sides until you remove the entire corrosion, and nothing remains of it in depth.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super loca cauterizata sulphur tritum cum oleo, donec eradicentur escharae omnes, et omnis corruptio.	 Then leave it for three days, and place over the cauterized places ground sulfur with oil until all scabs are removed and all corrosion.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis generantibus carnem.	 Then treat it with ointments that cause flesh to grow.
Si ergo uides, quod post tres dies caro nascitur natiuitate sana, in qua non est corruptio, est bonum.	 If therefore you see that after three days flesh is born through healthy growth, in which there is no corrosion, it is good.
Et si non: tunc itera cauterium super illud quod remansit ex locis corruptis.	 And if not: then repeat the cautery over what remains from the corrupted places.
Et corrodens medicatur quandoque cum medicina acuta.	 And corrosion is sometimes treated with a strong medicine.
Ipsa namque surgit loco cauterii.	 Indeed, it arises in the place of cautery.
Verumtamen cauterium cum igne est uelocioris iuuamenti: et ego quidem iam dixi cauterizationem eius cum medicina acuta in diuisione: accipe ergo eam illic quando ea indiges.	 However, cautery with fire is quicker in helping: and I myself have already said that the cauterization of it with a strong medicine is in the division; therefore take it there when you need it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Clauis, et Verucis.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing nails and warts.
Caput LV.	 Chapter 50.
Multotiens accidit in inferioribus partibus pedum haec aegritudo: et est res grossa, filtrata, quae laedit pedem.	 It often happens that this illness occurs in the lower parts of the feet and is bulky, filtered, which injures the foot.
Et cauterium quidem in eis est secundum duos modos: cauterium cum igne, et cauterium cum aqua calida.	 Indeed, cautionery in these [cases] is according to two modes: cauterization with fire and cauterization with hot water.
Quantum autem cum igne est, ut ignias cauterium concauum simile pennae uulturis: quod fiat ex ferro, secundum quantitatem quod contineat clauum ab omni parte: et sit subtilium marginum.	 As for the cautery with fire, it is made concave like a bird's feather; which should be made of iron, according to the size that contains the nail from all sides; and it should be thin on the edges.
Deinde depone ipsum ignitum super clauum.	 Then place the hot iron on the nail.
Deinde reuolue manum cum cauterio in circumitu claui, donec perueniat cauterium ad profunditatem claui: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, donec incipiat emittere pus.	 Then turn the hand with the hot iron around the nail until the hot iron reaches the depth of the nail; and let it be for three days, until it begins to emit pus.
Deinde emplastra ipsum cum maluis syluestribus, contritis cum sale: et dimitte emplastrum super ipsum in nocte.	 Then plaster it with wild herbs crushed with salt; and let the plaster remain on it at night.
Ipse enim eradicabitur ex radicibus suis.	 It will be uprooted from its roots.
Deinde cura locum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	 Then treat the place with a good ointment for flesh until it is healed.
Quod si sunt non conuersi, et multotiens accidunt in superficie corporis, praecipue in manibus et pedibus: tunc administres in eis cauterium cum aqua calida: et est, ut accipias cannulam ex aere, aut ferro, aut ex penna uulturis: et depone eam super clauum, aut althelul.	 If they are not converted and often recur on the surface of the body, especially in hands and feet; then administer cautery with hot water: and it is, that you receive a cannula from brass, iron, or from an eagle's feather; and place it on the nail or ulcer.
Deinde proiice in cannulam ex aqua calida quantitatem paucam: retine manum tuam, et tu reuolue eam cum compressione manus tuae parumper, ut imprimatur margo cannulae in radice claui, et inueniat aqua calida uiam ad profundum, ad radicem claui: et expectet infirmus parumper super mordicationem aquae calidae hora una.	 Then pour a small amount of hot water into the cannula; hold your hand and turn it with the pressure of your hand for a while, so that the tip of the cannula is pressed against the root of the nail, and let the hot water find its way to the depth, to the root of the nail: and let the patient wait for a short time on the bite of the hot water for one hour.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, nam clauus eradicatur cum radicibus suis.	 Then let it go, as the nail will be uprooted with its roots.
Ita fac cum eis uno post unum, donec uenias super omnes qui ex eis sunt in corpore.	 Do this to them one by one, until you have reached all who are affected by it in the body.
Deinde cura eos postquam eradicantur, cum eo quod generat carnem ex unguentis.	 Then care for them after they have been uprooted, with that which generates flesh from ointments.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tremore.	 Chapter on cauterizing tremor.
Caput LVI.	 Chapter 66.
Quando accidit alicui Tremor ex frigore in neruo, aut ex febre quartana, aut alio: tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis, aut quinque super spondiles dorsi, et inter omnem spondilem cauterio, et in pectore eius cauterio, et super stomachum eius cauterio.	 When trembling happens to anyone in a nerve due to cold, or quartan fever, or something else: then it is necessary that you cauterize it with four or five cauteries on the dorsal vertebrae, and with a cautery between each vertebra, and with a cautery on its chest, and with a cautery on its stomach.
Tremor enim quiescit cum cauterio oliuari, et festinat sanitas aegritudinis frigidae.	 The trembling ceases with cauterization by oil, and hastens the health of cold sickness.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Albathir.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing Albatheer (Albucasis).
Caput LVII.	 Chapter LVII.
Quandoque expelluntur in corpore Albathir foedae, id est, pustulae, quae fiunt a materiis grossis corruptis.	 Sometimes Albathir expels from the body fetid matter, that is, pustules, which are produced by corrupted thick materials.
Oportet ergo in primis cum apparent, ut cauterizentur super omne caput pustulae cauterio subtili cum ligno myrti, cuius extremitas accensa est cum igne.	 Therefore, first when they appear, it is necessary that they be cauterized over every head of the pustule with a subtle cautery and myrtle wood, whose tip is ignited with fire.
Aut cum radice aristolochiae longae.	 Or with a root of long arista-lochia (Aristolochia).
Aut cum cauterio lenticulari.	 Or with a lenticular cautery.
Et quandoque cauterizantur ademenul, in principio expulsionis suae secundum hunc modum: et non augentur: et disrumpitur superfluitas faciens eos, et sanatur ex eis.	 And sometimes they are cauterized with ademenes (adena), at the beginning of its expulsion according to this method; and they do not increase; and the excess is cut open making them, and heals from them.
Verumtamen oportet ut fiat illud post euacuationem cum phlebotomia.	 However, it must be done after evacuation with phlebotomy (bloodletting).
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fluxu sanguins ex arteria in uulnere.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in bleeding from an artery in a wound.
Caput LVIII.	 Chapter LVIII.
Multotiens accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, quae incisa est apud uulnus, quod accidit extrinsecus, aut apud incisionem apostematis, aut cauterium membri, et similia eis: et fit difficile abscindere eum.	 Many times there is bleeding from an artery which has been cut at a wound, which happens externally, or at the incision of an abscess, or cauterization of a member, and similar cases; and it is difficult to separate it.
Cum ergo accidit alicui illud, tunc propera cum manu tua ad orificium arteriae, et pone super ipsum digitum tuum indicem: et stringe eum multum, donec obsessus sit sanguis sub digito tuo, et non egrediatur ex eo aliquid.	 Therefore, when it happens to someone, then you quickly go with your hand to the opening of the artery, and place your index finger upon it; and press strongly, until the blood is compressed under your finger, and nothing escapes from it.
Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	 Then place in fire a small oil lamp cautionery, and many of them more: and blow upon it until they become very hot.
