Quando ergo uis ut cadant, pulueriza super eas aliquid ex aloe trito, aut salem, aut cinerem: et cadent statim.	 When you want them to fall (the clots), sprinkle something from crushed aloes, salt or ashes over them and they will fall immediately.
¶ Partis Secundae Finis.	 End of the second part.
¶ Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars III.	 Book of Surgery by Albucasis, Third Part.
¶ Sermo uniuersalis de restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus.	 Universal discourse on the restoration, dislocation, and treatment of twists, and similar conditions.
Caput I.	 Chapter I.
Hoc Capitulum etiam multotiens est necessarium in arte Medicinae, et est restauratio fracturae, et dislocationis accidentium in ossibus.	 This chapter is also often necessary in the art of medicine and it is the restoration of broken bones and dislocations that occur in bones.
Scitote o Filii, quia iactant se de hoc Capitulo stolidi medicorum et uulgi, et qui non inspexerunt unquam antiquorum librum, neque legerunt ex eo literam.	 Know that the foolish doctors and common people boast about this chapter and those who have never examined an ancient book or read a single letter from it.
Et propter hanc caussam fit, quod iste modus ex scientiis in terra nostra est priuatus.	 And because of this reason, the method is rare among our scholars on earth.
Et ego non obuiaui in eo unquam bono omnino, et non adeptus sum ex eo illud, quod sum adeptus nisi propter longitudinem lectionis librorum antiquorum, et studium super intellectum eorum, donec extraxi scientiam illius ex eis.	 And I have never encountered a good example of this method and I have not acquired that knowledge from it except for the length of reading ancient books and my dedication to understanding them until I extracted that knowledge from them.
Deinde adhaesi experimento et studio longitudine uitae meae.	 Then I attach myself by experience and study to the length of my life.
Et iam descripsi uobis ex illo in hoc Capitulo totum quod continet scientia mea: et super quod praeteriit experimentum meum, postquam abbreuiaui illud uobis, et liberaui illud ex occupatione elongationis, et abbreuiaui illud fine abbreuiationis, et ostendi illud fine declinationis: et formaui in eo formas multas ex formis instrumentorum quae administrantur in eo, cum sit ex additione declinationis, sicut feci in duobus Capitulis praecedentibus.	 And now I have described to you in this Chapter everything that contains my knowledge: and beyond what my experience has passed, after I have abbreviated it for you, and freed it from the occupation of elongation, and abbreviated it at the end of abbreviation, and shown it at the end of declination: and I have formed many shapes in it from the shapes of the instruments that are administered in it, as I did in two preceding Chapters.
¶ Summae, et collectiones ex esse fracturae ossium, ex eis quarum praemissio necessaria est, antequam incipiamus rememorationem membrorum fractorum, et diuersorum, si uniuscuiusque.	 The sums and collections of the fractures of bones, from those whose premise is necessary before we begin the remembrance of the fractured members, and various ones, if of each one.
Caput II.	 Chapter II.
Oportet, ut dicamus in prologo huius Capituli, summas sermonis, et capitula, ad quarum intellectum cogitur in primis artifex ad stationem super earum ueritatem: scilicet ut uos, et qui sunt prompti, sciant, uel addiscant hanc artem nobilem, et alii a uobis.	 It is necessary that we say in the prologue of this Chapter, the sums and chapters, to whose understanding the craftsman must be guided firstly on the truth of them: namely, so that you, and those prompt, may know or learn this noble art from it, and others from you.
Dico, ergo, quod quando accidit alicui fractura, aut dislocatio, aut torsio, aut casus: tunc oportet, ut properes in primis ad phlebotomandum eum, et soluendum ipsum, aut utraque simul: si non prohibeat aliquid, sicut debilitas uirtutis: aut est ille cui accidit aliquid ex illis puer, aut senex decrepitus: aut est tempus uehementis caloris, aut uehementis frigoris ualde.	 I say therefore, that when a fracture or dislocation or twisting or falling happens to someone, then it is necessary that you rush firstly to bleed him, and to dissolve himself, or both at the same time: if something does not prevent it, such as weakness of virtue; or it is he who has happened something of these things, a boy or an old man worn out; or it is a time of violent heat, or very violent cold.
Deinde sit contentus in cibo suo, oleribus frigidis, et carnibus auium, et haedorum: et prohibe uinum, et carnes grossas, et repleri ex cibis et omni cibo qui replet uenas sanguine.	 Then he should be content with his food, cold vegetables, and the flesh of beans and lentils; and forbid wine, thick meats, and to be filled from foods and every food that fills the veins with blood.
Donec quando securus sis ex apostemate calido, et non times effusionem materiei ad membrum: tunc redeat infirmus ad regimen suum primum cum quo cucurrit consuetudo eius.	Until you are secure from a hot abscess and no longer fear the outflow of matter to the member, then let the sick return to their first regimen with which their custom was accustomed.
Cum ergo incipit os fractum restaurari, tunc oportet, ut cibetur infirmus cibis nutrientibus nutrimento multo, grosso, graui, in quibus sit uiscositas: sicut cibaria facta ex tritico cocto cum aqua, et rizum, et capita, et pedes, et uentres uaccarum, et oua, et pisces recentes: et uinum grossum, et similia illis.	 When the fractured bone begins to heal, then it is necessary that the sick be fed with nutritious food in great quantity, thick, heavy, which contains viscosity; such as food made from boiled wheat and water, rice, heads of cattle, feet, abdomens of sheep, eggs, fresh fish, thick wine and similar things.
Cum hoc enim regimine fit coagulatio fracturae uelocius, et melius.	 For this diet makes the coagulation of the fracture quicker and better.
Et scias, quod ossa fracta, quando sunt in uiris qui sunt in prima senectute, et decrepitis, non est possibile, ut continuentur et consolidentur secundum naturam suam semper, propter exiccationem membrorum eorum: et consolidantur et continuantur quae ex eis sunt in fine lenitatis, sicut ossa puerornm paruorum.	 And you should know that fractured bones, when they are in men who are in the first old age and decrepit, it is not possible for them to be held together and consolidated according to their nature always, due to the drying out of their limbs; and they are consolidated and held together which come from them at the end of softness, like bones of small boys.
Verumtamen natura annectit super os fractum ex omni parte aliquid simile glutino, in quo est grossitudo, quo adhaeret et stringit ipsum, donec conglutinantur adinuicem, et ligantur adinuicem, donec uenit in fine fortitudinis et firmitudinis, sicut fuit in primis, donec non prohibet ipsum aliquid ab operationibus suis: et propter hanc caussam est necesse, ut ponas nutrimentum infirmi cibaria, in quibus sunt grauitas, et uiscositas, et grossitudo, sicut diximus.	 Nevertheless, nature connects something similar to a glue around the fractured bone from all sides, in which there is thickness, by which it adheres and tightens it until they are conglutinated on both sides, and bound together until it comes to the end of strength and firmness, as it was at first, until it does not prohibit anything from its operations; and for this reason it is necessary that you place nutriment for the sick food which has thickness, viscosity and heaviness, as we have said.
Et scias, quod fracturae species sunt diuersae, secundum diuersitatem membrorum: quoniam fractura cruris, est diuersa a fractura ossis capitis: et fractura ossis pectoris, est diuersa a fractura ossis dorsi: et similiter reliqua membra omnia diuersa existunt adinuicem: et ego ueni cum rememoratione omnis speciei fracturae expositae in Capitulo suo distinctae ab alia.	 And you should know that the species of fractures are diverse, according to the diversity of limbs; since a fracture of the leg is different from a fracture of the head bone; and a fracture of the chest bone is different from a fracture of the backbone; and similarly all other limbs are diverse among themselves; and I come with the reminder of every species of fractures explained in its own chapter.
Et diuersificantur species fracturae ossis etiam in seipsa.	 The species of bone fracture are also diversified within themselves.
Quoniam fit fractura eius arcuata, praeter quod accidant in ea astellae.	 Since the fracture is bow-shaped, there are also stellate occurrences in it. (In this context "stellate" refers to a star-like pattern or configuration.)
Et quandoque fit fractura eius secundum longitudinem ossis: et sunt fracturae eius satagiae, id est, astellae, et additiones procedentes, sicut sunt in calamo, cum aptatur cultello ad scribendum.	 And sometimes the fracture occurs along the length of the bone; and these are its stellate or star-like fractures, and extensions proceeding, just as they are in a reed, when it is cut with a knife for writing purposes. (In this context "stellate" refers to a star-like pattern or configuration.)
Et non procedentes: et est fractura cum uulnere et disruptione in capite: et est fractura fissura parua.	 And not proceeding; and there is a fracture with wound and disruption at the head, and there is a small crack fracture.
Et omni speciei est ingenium, uel instrumentum proprium in restauratione eius, secundum quod ueniet rememoratio eius, distincta in locis suis.	 And every species has a skill or its own specific tool for its restoration, according to how it will be remembered, distinguished in their respective places.
Et ex eo quo cognoscitur fractura ossis, est tortuositas eius, et ipsius eminentia: et apparitio eius sensui, et sonitus eius quando comprimis ipsum manu tua.	 And from that which the bone fracture is known, there is its tortuosity and elevation; and its appearance to the sense, and the sound it makes when you compress it with your hand.
Quando ergo non est in loco tortuositas apparens, neque sonitus apud tactum tuum cum tangis os cum agitatione, neque inuenit infirmus magnum dolorem: tunc non est illic fractura, imo possibile est, ut sit tortuositas, aut fissura parua: non ergo oportet, ut moueas ipsum cum manu et compressione omnino, imo pone super ipsum ex medicinis, quarum uenit rememoratio, post momentum illud quod conuenit loco: deinde stringatur strictura subtili.	 When therefore there is no tortuosity appearing in the place, nor a sound when you touch the bone with movement, nor does it produce a great pain; then there is no fracture there, indeed it may be a tortuosity or a small crack; therefore you should not move it with your hand and compression at all, instead put medicines on top of it, according to how it will be remembered, after a suitable time: then it is strained by a ligature made finely. (In this context, "ligature" refers to a medical bandage or suture used for binding wounds together.)
Et scias, quod locus quando arcuatur, et scinditur in duo, praeter quod accidant in eo satagiae, uerumtamen remouetur omnis pars a compari sua: tunc oportet tibi, ut incipias ab hora tua ad rectificationem eius, aequando ipsum antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	 And know that a place becomes arched and is split into two, except there are stellate occurrences in it; however, all parts should be moved away from their comparison: then you must begin from your hour for its correction, equalizing it before a hot abscess occurs to it. (In this context "stellate" refers to a star-like pattern or configuration.)
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum, tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec quiescat apoestema.	If a boil occurs warm, then let it be left for some days until the boil subsides.
Deinde aequa ipsum secundum quemcunque modum potest ex lenitate et ingenio.	 Then cut (the boil) according to whatever method can be done with kindness and skill.
Et scias, quod restauratio eius, et ipsius aequatio, est facilior quam ossis, in quo accidunt satagiae.	 And know that the healing (of the wound) and its setting (in order), is easier than of a bone, in which there are fractures.
Deinde stringe ipsum, secundum quod ueniet tibi rememoratio eius.	 Then suture it, according to what comes to your mind regarding its healing.
Si uero in osse sunt satagiae, tunc necessaria est extensio huius membri fracti ex duabus partibus, si manus sit, aut pes: aut cum manu tua, si membrum est paruum: aut cum duobus funibus, aut cum fune et manu.	 If there are fractures in the bone, then it is necessary to stretch this broken limb by two parts, whether it be a hand or a foot; or with your hand, if the member is small; or with two ropes, or with a rope and your hand.
Et sit positio tua qua ponis membrum super locum aequalem, secundum figuram suam naturalem, donec quando extenduntur partes membri fracti: tunc conare, ut redire facias illas additiones omni ingenio, et secundum quemcunque modum potes in locis suis: et caue secundum fortitudinem tuam, ne accidat super infirmum per operationem tuam dolor, neque laesio: et conare secundum fortitudinem tuam, ut applices unum duorum ossium cum socio suo, secundum meliores formas.	 Let the position you place the limb on be equal to its natural shape on a flat surface, until the parts of the broken limb extend; then try with all your skill and in any way possible to bring back these additions (to their places); and be careful according to your strength so that no pain or injury occurs due to your operation, nor damage; and try according to your strength to apply one bone to its companion, according to the best forms.
Et oportet in illa hora, ut tentes et tangas ipsum manu tua.	 And it is necessary that you try and touch it with your hand at that hour.
Si ergo uides illic aliquid diuersum, rectifica ipsum, et aequa illud per quantitatem tuae uirtutis.	 If you see something irregular there, correct it, and set (the bone) straight according to your ability.
Et caue extensionem uehementem, et compressionem fortem, sicut faciunt multi stolidorum.	 And avoid violent extension and strong compression, as many fools do.
Multotiens enim faciunt accidere per operationem illam suam apostema calidum, aut contractionem in membro: sicut iam uidimus illud ex operationibus eorum multotiens.	 For often they make a boil occur due to their operation, or contraction in the limb; as we have already seen from their operations many times.
Deinde annecte post aequationem, et decentem operationem, et stricturam illius membri, et quietem, et tranquillitatem: et mone infirmum super ipsum.	 Then bind (the limb) after the setting, and a proper operation, and a tightening of the member, and quiet, and calm; and warn the patient about it.
Et fac ipsum cauere, ne moueat ipsum in hora suarum uigiliarum, et somni sui apud reuolutionem suam, et agitationem suam, et apud egestionem suam, et omnes motus suos ultima uirtute sua.	 The translation of the given Latin sentence is: "And make him take care not to move it during his hours of sleep, and his sleep, and his restlessness, and during his digestion, and all its movements with utmost strength.
Et ut caueat, ne sit positio membri positio cum qua sequatur dolor.	 "And let him take care that the position of the member which follows pain is not maintained.
Quod est, quia quando sentit in dispositione positionis membri dolorem, aut laesionem: tunc oportet, ut permutes ipsum ad dispositionem aliam ab illa cum qua non sentiat dolorem.	 "What is meant by this, is that when it feels pain or injury in the position of a member, then it must be moved to another position from which it does not feel pain.
Et caue cum illo, ut sit positio eius illa aequalis, recta: ut non accidat in membro tortuositas, quando restauratur.	 "And let him take care that his position is even and straight so that no deformity occurs in the member when it is being restored.
Et qualitas stricturae membri fracti est, secundum quod narro.	 "And the quality of the immobilization of a fractured member, as I have said.
Scias, quod membra fracta diuersificantur in paruitate sua, et eorum magnitudine, et ipsorum forma.	 "Know that fractured members are classified according to their size, dimension, and shape.
Quae ergo ex eis sunt parua, sicut brachium, et digitus, et focile, et similia eis, tunc oportet, ut sit inuolutio panni mollis, subtilis.	 "Those which are small such as the arm, finger, club foot, and similar, then it should be wrapped in a soft, fine fabric.
Quae autem ex eis sunt grossa, sicut coxa, et crus, oportet ut sit in eis inuolutio lata, dura.	 "But those which are large such as the thigh and leg, there should be a wide, hard wrapping.
Quoniam ligamentum latum, connectit membrum magnum, et stringit ipsum ab omni parte strictura aequali, ita quod non ingreditur ipsum macula.	 "Because a broad bandage unites a large member and compresses it equally from all sides with an equal immobilization so that no mark penetrates.
Deinde incipe post euacuationem tuam ab aequatione ponere linimentum conueniens ad illud, in stuppa leni super locum fracturae ipsius.	 "Then begin to apply a suitable ointment after evacuation on the equal part, on a soft cotton over the location of the fracture.
Deinde incipe inuoluere ligamentum super locum fracturae ipsius tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod meretur membrum: et stringe manum tuam parumper cum ligamento.	 "Then begin to wrap the bandage over the location of the fracture with three or four layers, depending on the member's deserving, and tighten your hand slightly with the bandage.
Deinde uade cum eo ad partem superiorem a loco fracturae, et stringe minus quam fuit strictura tua, qua strinxisti locum fractum.	 "Then go with him to the upper part from the location of the fracture and loosen less than your previous immobilization on the fractured location.
Deinde elonga te cum inuolutione a loco fracturae parumper, et mollifica stricturam paulatim, donec capias ex loco sano rem magnam.	 Then prolong yourself slightly with a slight rotation from the place of the fracture, and gradually soften the constriction until you seize a large amount from a healthy place.
Deinde accipe uittam aliam, et inuolue eam iterum super locum fractum inuolutionibus.	 Then take another poultice and apply it again over the broken place with repeated rotations.
Postea uade cum inuolutione ad partem inferiorem a fractura.	 Go downwards, with a slight rotation, to the lower part from the fracture.
Et sit operatio tua in strictura inuolutionis, et mollificatione eius, secundum quod diximus in inuolutione prima superiore.	 And make your operation in the constriction of the rotation and its softening, according to what we said in the first rotation above.
Deinde pone inter inuolutiones ex stuppa leni, aut panno, cum quo aequetur tortuositas fracturae, si est in ea tortuositas: et si non, non ponas in ea aliquid.	 Then put between the rotations (bandages) of soft wool or cloth, which matches the curvature of the fracture, if there is a curvature in it; and if not, do not place anything on it.
Deinde inuolue super ipsam uittam aliam.	 Then apply another poultice over it (the bandages).
Postea aequa super has inuolutiones astellas decenter factas statim, si non est in loco inflatio, neque apostema calidum.	 Then place equal stars (small poultices) evenly over these rotations, immediately if there is no swelling or a hot abscess in the area.
Si autem in ea est inflatio, aut apostema: tunc pone super eam quod sedet illud apostema, et auferat inflationem: et dimitte eam aliquot diebus.	 If there is swelling or an abscess in the area; then place over it what sits on that abscess and removes the swelling; and let it be for some days.
Deinde stringe super ipsam tunc astellas.	 Then bind over these small poultices (stars).
Et sint Astellae ex medietatibus cannae latae, rasae, formatae sapienter: aut sint ex ligno unde fiunt cribra, quae fiunt ex pino, aut geraid, id est, ramis palmae, aut calingi: et sit amplitudo omnis Astellae, secundum hanc formam, et hanc eandem figuram.	 And let the small poultices (stars) be from the middle parts of wide reeds, shaved and wisely formed; or they can be from wood where sieves are made, which are made from pine, yew, palm branches, or calingi; and let the width of all the poultices be according to this form and this same shape.
Verumtamen oportet, ut Astella quae ponitur super ipsam tracturam, sit grossior et latior parumper, quam reliquae Astellae: et longitudo Astellae sit secundum quod licet membro ex magnitudine et paruitate.	 However, it is necessary that the poultice placed over the fracture be slightly larger and wider than the others; and the length of the poultice should be according to what is suitable for the limb in size and smallness.
Deinde stringe super Astellas cum uitta alia, secundum stricturam primam eandem.	 Then bind over the poultices with another poultice, according to the first constriction (bandage).
Deinde liga desuper cum filis decenter, secundum quod diximus de strictura: et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae plus: et quanto plus elongatur a fractura sit, strictura minor.	 Then bind above with threads properly, as we have said regarding the stricture: and it is, that your stricture be over the place of the fracture more: and as it is more elongated from the fracture, the stricture is lesser.
Et oportet, ut sint fila media in grossitudine et subtilitate, et sint ex lino molli.	 It is necessary that the threads be of a medium size and fineness, and be made of soft linen.
Quoniam si fila sunt grossa, sicut uidi ex operatione stolidorum ponentium fila sua ex chordis lini tortis, est error magnus: quoniam cadit strictura cum eis extra qualitatem.	 Since if the threads are thick, as I have seen from the operation of foolish ones placing their threads from twisted cords of coarse linen, it is a great mistake: since the stricture falls with them out of quality.
Et fila subtilia iterum non conueniunt: quoniam tu non consequeris per stricturam cum eis illud quod uis.	 And fine threads again do not fit: since you will not achieve with the stricture what you want.
Et non oportet, ut sit inter astellam et astellam minus quam digitus.	 It is not necessary that there be less than a finger's breadth between the awl and the awl.
Quod si laeditur infirmus per extremitates astellarum post stricturam in locis sanis: tunc pone sub eis ex stuppa leni, aut lana carminata, donec nihil laedatur ex illo.	 If the weak one is hurt by the tips of the awls after the stricture in healthy places: then place under them with wool felt or carded wool, until nothing is hurt from it.
Quando autem est fractura cum uulnere, et accidit disruptio in cute, ego ueniam cum rememoratione eius in capitulo secundum singularitatem.	 When there is a fracture with a wound, and it happens that the break occurs in the skin, I will come with the reminder of this in the second chapter concerning special cases.
Et scias, quod non omne membrum fractum oportet ut stringatur cum astellis a primo die.	 And know that not every fractured member needs to be bound with awls from the first day.
Quod est, quia membrum quando est magnum, non oportet ut ponas superipsum astellas, nisi post quinque dies, aut septem, aut plus, secundum securitatem tuam ab euentu apostematis calidi.	 Because when the member is large, it is not necessary to place upper awls on it, unless after five days, or seven, or more, according to your safety from the risk of a hot abscess.
Et iste est modus emplastrorum, quibus restaurabant antiqui, quae ponuntur super fracturam et dislocationem.	 And this is the method of plasters, which the ancients placed on a fracture and dislocation.
¶ Modus Emplastri communis abbreuiati, restaurans fracturam, conueniens pluribus complexionibus, praecipue mulieribus, et pueris: quoniam est ex eo super quod non uincit calor, neque frigus.	¶ Common method of plasters abbreviated, restoring the fracture, suitable for multiple constitutions, especially women and children: since it is from that which heat does not conquer nor cold.
Et est, ut accipias ex puluere molendini, et est medulla farinae quae pendet in parietibus molendini apud motum molae: et conficias ipsum sicut est, praeter quod cribelles ipsum cum albugine oui: et pone confectionem eius non spissam, neque subtilem.	 And it is to receive from the flour mill powder, and it is the marrow of the wheat that hangs on the walls of the mill near the movement of the millstone: and make it as follows, except you sift it with egg white: and place the mixture of it not thick, nor thin.
Deinde utere eo.	 Then use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, restaurantis fracturam, et dislocationem, et torsionem.	 Another method of plaster (bandage), for setting a fracture, dislocation and twisting.
Recipe almess, et laudani, et acaciae, et enulae, et mugath: et suc, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V et alethil ʒ XX terantur omnia, et cribellentur, et misceantur cum aqua alethil: aut cum albugine oui, si complexio infirmi est calefacta.	 Prepare almess, laudanum, acacia, enula, and mugath; and boil all of them with 10 parts of myrrh, 5 parts of each aloes, and 20 parts of alethil. Let everything be ground and sifted, then mix it with water of alethil or with sheep's milk white if the bandage is heated for a sick person.
Deinde utere hoc emplastro.	 Then use this plaster (bandage).
Nam ipsum est bonae compositionis, restaurat ossa fracta uelociter, et confert pluribus hominibus.	 For it is of good composition, quickly sets broken bones and helps many people.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, quod etiam confert fracturae et torsioni.	 Another method of plaster (bandage), which also helps with a fracture and twisting.
Recipe mugath, et mess, et alteae albae, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V acaciae ʒ VI boli armeni ʒ XX terantur omnia contritione multa, et cribellentur, et conficiantur cum aqua, aut albugine oui: et administrentur.	 Prepare mugath, mess, white alteae, all with 10 parts of myrrh, 5 parts of each aloes, 6 parts of acacia, and 20 parts of ground Armenian pitch. Let everything be ground well and sifted, then boil it with water or sheep's milk white, and administer (the mixture).
¶ Modus Emplastri ad iuncturas, et ossa separata ex locis suis: et sedat dolorem accidentem eis, et scissuram ossis, et fracturam.	 Another method of plaster (bandage) for joints and bones separated from their places; it relieves pain and swelling, and heals a broken bone.
Sumatur lana succida, et submergatur in aceto, et oleo decocto: et ponatur super locum.	 Wool grease is collected, immersed in vinegar and boiled oil; it is placed on the location.
Et in hoc quidem Emplastro non est uirtus restaurationis, sed est bonum in sedatione apostematis calidi: et expellit dolores proprie.	 And indeed, there is no virtue of healing in this plaster (bandage), but it is good for the healing of hot abscesses; and it expels pain specifically.
¶ Modus Emplastri, quod restaurat os fractum.	 Another method of plaster (bandage) that sets a broken bone.
Sume folia fici surdi, et folia papaueris syluestris: et tere omnia, et fac emplastrum ex utrisque.	 Take the leaves of wild fig and the leaves of silvestrous papaver; grind them all and make a plaster from both.
¶ Modus Emplastri abbreuiati, administrati apud restaurationem fracturae ossis: et quando tu uis resolutionem residui apostematis.	 Another method of shortened plaster (bandage), administered for the healing of a broken bone; and when you want the removal of the remaining abscess.
Recipe radicis alteae, et camomillae, et florum uiolarum, et farinae herbi, omnium ana partem unam: terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum uino, si non est membrum calefactum.	 Prepare a mixture of the root of the marshmallow plant (altheae), chamomile, herb violet flowers, and barley flour, all in equal parts: grind them all and mix them with wine, if the affected member is not already heated.
Si uero est calefactum, tunc confice illud cum aqua coriandri humidi, aut cum aqua, et utere eo.	 If the affected member is already heated, then prepare it with water from moist coriander seeds, or simply use this preparation.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius fortioris in resolutione, quam istud primum, quando accidit apostema durum apud restaurationem membri.	 Another stronger method of plaster for resolution, stronger than the first, when there is a hard abscess during restoration of a member.
Recipe radicis alteae, et seminis lini, et balaustiae, et melliloti, et samsuci, et floris uiolarum, et camomillae, omnium ana, partem unam, terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum aqua salicis, aut cum aqua dulci, aut cum uino.	 Prepare a mixture of the root of marshmallow plant (altheae), flax seeds, beechwood resin, licorice, sesame seeds, asafetida, violet flowers and chamomile, all in equal parts: grind them all and mix with water of willow, sweet water or wine.
Totum illud secundum caliditatem membri, et quietem caloris eius.	 Apply this preparation to the affected member according to its heat and the calmness of the heat.
Hippocrates uero non dixit in libro suo, quod ponatur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius, nisi caerotum factum ex caera, et oleo: non aliud: et narrauit, ut sit medium inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem.	 Hippocrates did not say in his book to apply on a broken member during its restoration unless it is made of beeswax and oil; he does not mention anything else, and he said that it should be between coarseness and subtlety.
Galeno autem uisum est, ut ponantur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius res, in quibus est exiccatio caliditatis, sicut myrrha, et aloes et olibanum, et similia eis ex eis quae narrauimus.	 Galenus saw it fit that substances with a heating property be applied on a broken member during its restoration, such as myrrh, aloes, frankincense and similar ones from the substances mentioned earlier.
¶ Modus Emplastri quod confert ad laesionem et dolorem.	 Another plaster method for injuries and pain relief.
Recipe mugath, et ciceris, et capillorum hominis incisorum, aut pennae auis, et alteae, et salis partes aequales: terantur, et cribellentur, et conficiantur: et fiat ex eo emplastrum.	 Prepare a mixture of mugwort, chickpeas, human hair (either cut or feathers of birds), marshmallow root and salt in equal parts: grind and sift it, and make plaster out of this mixture.
Quantitas autem secundum quam oportet, ut remaneat ligatura, deinde soluatur, est, ut consideres tunc, si non accidit infirmo dolor, neque pruritus, neque mouetur os fractum a loco suo: tunc non resoluas ipsum diebus multis.	 The amount that should remain tied (the ligature) is as follows: consider if there is no pain or itching, or the bone does not move from its place; if so, do not untie it for several days.
Quod si accidat ei in loco pruritus uehemens, aut dolor inquietans, aut inflatio: tunc propera, et solue in hora ipsum, et aufer emplastrum ab eo: et accipe pannum lenem, aut spongiam marinam lenem, humidam: et submerge eam in aqua tepida, et ablue cum ea locum, donec quiescat pruritus, et sedetur dolor.	 If it happens to him at the place of itching intensely, or distressing pain, or swelling: then hurry up and dissolve it within an hour, and remove the plaster from him; and take a soft cloth or a soft sea sponge, moist; and immerse it in warm water, and wash the place with it until the itching ceases and the pain subsides.
Deinde dimitte membrum quiescere una hora.	 Then let the member rest for an hour.
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam succidam, submersam in aceto et oleo, aut oleo rosato: et liga super ipsum nocte una, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido, et quiescat inflatio membri, et remoueatur dolor eius.	 Then place on it a soft woolen cloth, immersed in vinegar and oil, or rose oil; and bind over it at night until you are safe from hot infection, and the swelling of the member subsides, and the pain disappears.
Deinde itera ipsum ad stricturam subtilem, et emplastrum paruum: et non stringas ipsum constrictione tua prima, et subtilia cum eo, donec sanetur.	 Then repeat on it a subtle bandage and small plaster; do not bind it with your first compression and fine ones, until it is healed.
Quod si uides, quod apostema, et rubedo, et dolor, et inflatio, et omnia accidentia iam remota sunt penitus, et indiges emplastro et strictura, tunc itera illud sicut fecisti in primis aequaliter.	 If you see that the abscess, redness, pain, swelling and all the other occurrences have been removed entirely, and you need plaster and bandage, then repeat it as you did at first, equally.
Quod si non accidit membro aliquid ex eis quae diximus, tune non soluas ipsum, nisi post tres dies, aut quatuor, aut quinque, aut septem.	 If nothing of what we mentioned happens to the member, then do not dissolve it before three days, or four, or five, or seven.
Et quando que dimittitur uiginti diebus totum illud, secundum quod apparet tibi ex solutione membri, sicut diximus, donec quando adhaeret fractura, et approximat coagulatio carnis super eam: adde etiam tunc in strictura plus quam strictura tua prima tota: et adde etiam in ingrossatione cibi infirmi, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius.	 And when it is released after twenty days, according to what you see from the dissolution of the member as we said, until a fracture adheres and coagulation of flesh grows over it: add also at that time more than your first bandage in the bandage; and add also in the thickening of food, according to what was previously remembered.
Si autem uides locum fracturae iam exiccari, et extenuari plus quam oportet: tunc scias, quod nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad ipsum.	 If you see that the place of the fracture is already drying out and thinning more than necessary: then know that nourishment is prevented from reaching it.
Embroca ergo ipsum cum aqua tepida apud omnem uicem qua soluis ipsum, et sit illud in omnibus tribus diebus, et alleuia stricturam parumper.	 Heat the embrocation with warm water in every place where you dissolve it, and let it be in all three days, and apply a ligature slightly.
Per hanc ergo operationem currit ad membrum nutrimentum, et sanatur uelociter.	 Through this operation, nourishment flows to the member, and it heals quickly.
Illud autem quod faciunt stolidi restauratores ex fractura membri uice alia, quando non restauratur in primis, secundum quod oportet, et restauratur secundum tortuositatem, est error ex operatione eorum, et timor magnus: et si esset rectum, dixissent illud antiqui in libris suis, et operati fuissent cum eo.	 But what the foolish restorers do in place of fractured members when it is not first restored as required, and it is restored according to a curve, is an error from their operation, and great fear: and if it were correct, they would have said this in their ancient books, and operated with it.
Et ego non uidi alicubi eorum uestigium in illo omnino, et rectius est, ut non fiat illud.	 And I never saw any trace of them [the error] in this at all, and it is better not to do that.
¶ De factura accidente in capite.	 Chapter on the making of a fracture in the head.
Caput III.	 Chapter III.
Species fracturae sunt diuersae, et figurae eius multae: et caussae eius sunt distinctae.	 The types of fractures are various, and their shapes are numerous; and their causes are distinct.
Nam ex fractura est quae fit a percussione cum ense: et percussio aufert os totum usquequo peruenit ad siphac, quod est sub osse, sicut facit axia in ligno: et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Axialis.	 For a fracture is that which occurs by striking with a sword: and striking removes the bone to the extent it reaches the syphac (which is under the bone), just as an axe does in wood: and for this reason, this type of fracture is called an Axial fracture.
Aut ensis incidit quiddam ossis, et incidit faciem eius, et non penetrat incisio usque ad ultimum eius: et nominatur haec species fracturae Kalaan, id est, Leuatio absolute.	 Or the sword cuts something of the bone and cuts its face, but does not cut through with the incision to the end of it: and this type of fracture is called a Calaan (meaning an Absolute Lifting).
Et est uulnus duarum fracturarum, aut magnum, aut paruum.	 And there are two types of wounds, either large or small.
Et ex fractura est, quae est contritio, aut attritio: et caussa eius est percussio cum lapide, aut casus super lapidem, aut eis similia.	 And from a fracture is one which is crushed or rubbed: and the cause of this is a blow with a stone, or falling on a stone, or similar things.
Et haec fractura est etiam aut penetrans, quae iam appropinquat panniculo, quod est sub osse: aut est in facie ossis: et est uulnus harum duarum fracturarum etiam aut paruum, aut magnum.	 And this fracture is also one that penetrates and approaches the pannicle (which is under the bone): or it is on the face of the bone: and this type of wound is also among those two types, either small or large.
Et ex fractura est, quae est occulta in osse in subtilitate capilli: et est fissura parua, et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Capillaris.	 And from a break is that which is hidden within the bone in the subtlety of hair; and it is a small fissure, and because of this it is called this kind of fracture Capillary.
Et ex eis est fractura, quae fit a casu, aut percussione lapidis, et eis similium, quae faciunt ingredi laminam ossis ad interiora, et fit loco concauitas: sicut accidit caldariis aeris, quando occurrit eis percussio, et ingreditur pars eorum ad interiora.	 And from these (things) is a fracture that happens from an accident or impact of a stone and similar things which cause a lamina of the bone to enter within; and it makes a hollow place: just as it happens to the bellows of air, when they are struck, and part of them enters within.
Et plurimum quidem fit illud in capitibus humidorum ossium, sicut sunt capita puerorum.	 And indeed, this (kind of fracture) is most often found in the moist bones of the head, such as those of children.
Et fiunt omnibus istis speciebus fracturae satagiae separatae, et ego ueniam cum rememoratione illius totius in loco suo.	 And all these kinds of fractures (are accompanied by) swelling and separation; and I shall return with a reminder of the whole in its place.
Et cognoscimus omnes has species fracturae per detectionem super eam, et inquisitionem earum cum tentis, et ablationem carnium corruptarum, quae sunt super eas.	 And we know all these kinds of fractures by the examination of them and investigation with probes, and removal of rotten flesh that is on top of them.
Species uero Capillaris cognoscitur per hoc, quod detegitur super os, et abstergitur, et linitur super ipsum cum encaustro: fractura enim apparet nigra.	 The Capillary kind (of fracture) is recognized by this, that it appears on the bone, and is scraped away, and a ligature is applied on top of it with pitch: for the fracture appears black.
In curatione autem fracturae, considera in primis accidentia infirmi: tunc si uides ex accidentibus quod significet significatione manifesta super timorem, sicut uomitus cholerae, et extensio, et amissio intellectus, et abscisio uocis, et syncopis, et febris acuta, et egressus oculorum, et rubedo eorum, et similia eis ex accidentibus in pluribus dispositionibus, proculdubio non sanatur: et si uides accidentia non terrentia te, et speras salutem: tunc incipe curationem eius.	 In the treatment of a fracture, consider first the condition of the patient; then if you see that there are indications of illness from the accidents (symptoms) themselves, as in cholera vomiting, extension, loss of intellect, loss of voice, fainting, fever, eye discharge or redness, similar symptoms in other disorders, it will certainly not heal: and if you see the patient's condition is not terrifying and you hope for recovery; then begin its treatment.
Quod est, si uenit ad te uulneratus in primis cum uulneratur: et est illud in diebus hyemis, tunc oportet, ut studeas in ablatione ossis ante diem quartumdecimum secundum omnem dispositionem.	 If someone comes to you with a wound, and it is a fracture, it is during the winter days; then it is necessary that you study its excision (removal of bone) before the fourteenth day according to every situation.
Et si est in diebus aestatis, tunc oportet, ut properes remouere os ante diem septimum, antequam corrumpatur quod est sub osse ex panniculo, et accidant illa accidentia quae narrauimus.	 If it is in the days of summer, then it is necessary that you hasten to remove the bone before the seventh day, before it becomes rotten under the bone from the fat, and such accidents occur as we have described.
Quod si fractura ossis iam peruenit ad panniculum tangentem cerebrum, et est cum minutiis, et attractione: tunc oportet, ut incidas partem comminutam, et attritam, secundum quod narro tibi.	 If the fracture of the bone has already reached the fat touching the brain, and is with particles and traction: then it is necessary that you cut the fractured and smoothed part, according to what I have told you.
Et est, ut radas caput uulnerati: et detege super os secundum quemcunque modum possibile est tibi: et secundum figuram uulneris, et quod leue est super infirmum.	 It is necessary that you shave the head of the wounded: and bore into the bone according to whatever method is possible for you: and according to the shape of the wound, and what is light on the weak.
Quod si accidat tibi apud detectionem ossis fluxus sanguinis, aut apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet.	 If while boring into the bone there comes a flow of blood or a hot abscess: then oppose it with what is necessary.
Et est, ut impleas locum cum pannis infusis in uino, et oleo rosato: et facias quiescere uulnus, donec sedetur apostema, et sis securus a fluxu sanguinis.	 It is necessary that you fill the place with soaked rags in wine and rose oil: and let the wound rest until the abscess settles, and be secure from bleeding.
Deinde incipe in curatione ossis, et ablatione eius.	 Then begin in the treatment of the bone, and its removal.
Et illud fit secundum unum duorum modorum.	 And this is done according to one of two methods.
Modus quidem unus est, ut incidas os cum Incisorio strictae aciei: et haec est forma eius.	 One method is that you cut the bone with a sharp chisel: and this is its shape.
Dende administra Incisorium aliud post Incisorum latius eo parumper: et haec est forma eius.	 Then administer another chisel wider than the first: and this is its shape.
Deinde administra etiam Incisorium aliud latius etiam quam secundum.	 Then administer yet another chisel wider still.
Et modus secundus est, ut sit apud te numerus Incisoriorum diuersorum: quorum quaedam sint latiora quibusdam, et quaedam eorum breuiora quibusdam: et sint in ultimo acuitatis extremitatum suarum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut fuled: et utere facilitate in percussione super Incisorium, ut non concutiat caput, et laedat ipsum.	 And the second method is that you have a number of chisels of different sizes; some of which are wider than others, and some shorter than others: and they should be at the end of their sharpness, and made from iron or steel: and use them with ease when striking the chisel, so as not to strike the head, and hurt it.
Si autem os est forte, durum: tunc oportet, ut perfores in circumitu eius, antequam tu administres Incisoria, cum Terebris quae nominantur Terebra non profundantia: et non nominantur ita, nisi quoniam ipsa non pertranseunt terminum ossis carnei ad illud, quod est post ipsum: propterea, quod Terebro est extremitas rotunda super illud, quod est sub capite eius acuto, similis margini, et circulus paruus prohibet submergi, et pertransire spissitudinem ossis.	 If the bone is hard and firm: then it is necessary that you bore around its circumference before you administer Incision, with Terebris which are called Terebras, not penetrating too deeply; and they are not named thus, except because they do not pass beyond the bone's meaty limit to that which is behind it; for this reason, because the Terebrum has a rounded extremity above what is beneath its head and a sharp point below, similar to an edge, and a small circle prevents immersion, and passing through the bone's thickness.
Et conuenit tibi, ut accipias ex istis Terebris numerum multum, quorum unumquodque conueniat quantitati spissitudinis ossis, donec praesens sit tibi omni craneo Terebrum: cuius extremitatis acutae quantitas in longitudine et breuitate sit, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis illius cranei.	 It is necessary for you to take a large number of these Terebris, one of which should correspond to the thickness of the bone; until the present is to you all the Terebrum of the skull; whose sharp edge's length and width should be according to the thickness of that skull.
Et haec est forma trium specierum Terebrorum, uel Trepanorum.	 And this is the form of three kinds of Terebris or Trepans.
Qualitas autem perforandi in circumitu ossis fracti, est: ut ponas Terebrum super os, et reuoluas ipsum digitis tuis, donec scias, os iam penetratum esse.	 The quality of boring around the bone that is broken, is: you place the Terebrum on the bone and turn it with your fingers until you know the bone has been penetrated.
Deinde permuta Terebrum ad locum alium, et pone quod est inter omne foramen quantitatem grossitudinis radii, aut circiter illud.	 Then change the Terebrum to another place and place what is between every hole of the same thickness as a radius, or approximately so.
Deinde incide cum Incisoriis quod est inter omne foramen ex osse: et fac illud subtilius quam potes super illud ex fine leuitatis, sicut diximus, donec eradices os, aut manu tua, aut cum aliquo alio ex quibusdam instrumentis, quae parasti ad illud: sicut tenaliae, et forpices subtiles.	 Then cut with Incision what is between every hole from the bone; and do it more delicately than you can above that from the edge of thinness, as we have said, until you root out the bone, either with your hand or with some other instruments which you have prepared for that purpose: such as tenaliae and delicate forceps.
Et oportet, ut caueas omni cautela, ne tangat Terebrum, aut Incisorium aliquid ex siphac.	 And it is necessary to take care with every caution that the Terebrum or Incision does not touch anything from the siphac.
Cum ergo circumieris os perforando, et separatum fuerit a siphac, si fuerit continuum cum eo, et extraxeris ipsum, oportet ut radas, et aeques extremitatem eius quod remanet in osse cum instrumento alio simili Incisorio.	 When you are boring around the bone and it is separated from the siphac, if it is continuous with it and you extract it, it is necessary to root, and cut off an equal end of what remains in the bone with another similar instrument, like the Incision.
Verumtamen oportet, ut sit tenuis et subtilis magis aliis Incisoriis.	 It is necessary that it (the instrument) be thin and delicate more than other incising instruments.
Quod si remanet aliquid ex ossibus paruis, et satagiae: tunc accipe ea cum facilitate, cum eo quod est apud te ex instrumentis.	 If something remains of small bones and cartilage: then take it easily with what you have at hand from your instruments.
Deinde cura uulnus post illud cum liciniis, et unguentis quae diximus.	 Then care for the wound after that with linen strips, and ointments as I said.
Et modus alius operationis est facilis, prorsus longinquus a timore: quem dixit Galenus, et laudauit ipsum laude magna: et iste est sermo eius.	 Another method of operation is easy, completely remote from fear; which Galen said, and praised greatly; and this is his speech.
Necese est tibi in primis, ut incipias detegere partem ossis ex loco, in quo fractura est uehementior, et manifestior: donec quando detexeris illam partem, et posueris sub eo extremitatem huius Incisorii lenticularis, cuius haec est forma.	 You first must begin to expose the bone fragment from the place where the fracture is more severe and more noticeable; until you have exposed that part, and placed under it the end of this concave incising instrument, which has this shape.
Et pars lenticularis, lenis non incidit aliquid: et pars acuta eius in duabus lateribus eius uadens in longitudinem, sicut uides: ut sit pars lenticularis innixa ad siphac, facie eius incidente acuta in osse.	 The concave part does not cut anything; the sharp part of it on its two sides going along in length, as you see; so that the concave part be attached to the splint, the face of which the sharp part incises into the bone.
Deinde percute super Incisorium a parte una cum malleo paruo, donec incidas totum os cum facilitate, sicut reuoluitur: et tu sis securus ex panniculo, quod non accidat in eo accidens, quod timeas prorsus.	 Then strike on the incising instrument from one side with a small hammer, until you cut through the entire bone easily, as it turns; and be careful that no cloth accidentally falls into it, which you fear entirely.
Et si medicans non esset stultior hominum, et magis ignarus eius, nec esset dormiens, tunc si remaneret aliquid annexum ossi ex panniculo in quibusdam locis, incideret ipsum ab eo cum extremitate incisorii lenticularis ipsius, et liberaret ipsum ab eo cum facilitate.	 And if the physician were not more foolish than humans, and less ignorant of his art, nor asleep, then if something remained attached to the bone from the cloth in certain places, he would cut it off with the end of the concave incising instrument, and remove it easily.
Liberatur enim ab eo sine nocumento, et absque timore.	 It is freed from it without harm and without fear.
Et si fractura ossis non penetret usque ad panniculum, et illud quod abscinditur ab osse est facies eius, et remanent in ipso asperitas et satagiae subtiles: tunc oportet, ut radas illam asperitatem, et eradices illas satagias cum rasoriis subtilibus ex quibus praeparasti numerum diuersarum quantitatum, ut sit tibi possibile administrare ex eis in omni loco conuenientiora eorum, et rectiora ipsorum, secundum illud ad quod perducit te operatio, et ipsum os fractum, et figura eius.	 If the bone fracture does not penetrate to the cloth, and what is cut away from the bone is the face of it, and roughness and delicate cartilage remain in it; then it is necessary that you remove that roughness, and excavate those delicate cartilages with fine rasps, which you have prepared in various quantities, so that it is possible for you to apply more suitable ones in every place, and the ones themselves are straighter, according to what leads you in the operation, and the fractured bone and its shape.
Et oportet, ut administres in rasione tua, qua in primis radis os, latius illorum rasoriorum.	 And it is necessary that you administer according to your proportion, firstly cut the bone, more widely than the width of those scrapers.
Deinde utere post ipsum subtiliore eo.	 Then use (the instrument) after that with a finer one.
Et non cesses facere illud secundum continuitatem, donec peruenias ad administrandum tenuius, et subtilius eorum omnium.	 And do not cease doing it in continuity until you reach the point of administering thinner and finer than all of them.
In unaquaque autem fissurarum reliquarum paruarum capillarium, et fractura subtili, oportet ut administres curam, secundum illud quod perducit ad rectificationem eius.	 For each of the remaining small cracks and subtle breaks, it is necessary to administer care according to that which leads to its rectification.
Et est res quae non occultatur super omnem, cui in hac arte est quodlibet studium, et stetit super illud quod scripsimus, et ostendimus in fracturis magnis.	 And there is a thing that cannot be hidden upon all who have any interest in this art and it stands upon that which we have written and shown for large breaks.
Si autem panniculus detectus retinetur, quando tu eradicas os: tunc oportet, ut accipias pannum lini, secundum quantitatem uulneris, et submerge ipsum in oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super orificium uulneris.	 If however a small piece of skin is found while you are cutting bone: then it is necessary that you take a linen cloth, according to the size of the wound, and immerse it in rose oil, and place it over the opening of the wound.
Deinde accipe pannum alium duplicatum, aut triplicatum, et submerge ipsum in uino et oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super pannum primum: et fac illud quam facilius potes super illud, ut non grauetur siphac.	 Then take another cloth either doubled or tripled and immerse it in wine and rose oil, and place it on the first cloth: and do that as easily as possible above it, so that it does not become heavy.
Deinde administra supra ipsum ligamentum latum: et non stringas ipsum, nisi per quantitatem quae teneat uulnus tantum: et dimitte ipsum cum hac cura die uno, aut diebus duobus, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido.	 Then administer above it a wide ligature: and do not tighten it except to the size that holds the wound only: and leave it with this care for one day or two days until you are secure from hot inflammation.
Deinde solue ipsum, et administra post illud medicinas cum quibus est superflua siccitas: sicut radices lilii, et farina herbi, et puluis thuris, et aristolochia, et similia eis: et est, ut facias ex istis medicinis puluerem, qui puluerizetur super uulnus sicut sunt siccae.	 Then dissolve it, and administer afterwards medications with which excessive dryness is necessary: such as the roots of lilies, and oat flour, and turpentine resin, and aristolochia, and similar to these: and there is, so that you make a powder from these medicines, which is powdered over the wound like dry ones.
Et uniuersaliter administra in illo omnem medicinam de proprietate cuius est ut abstergat, et non mordicet.	 And universally administer in it every medication according to the property of which is to cleanse and not to irritate.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, ut uulnus in curatione tua sit limpidum: neque sit in ea sordes unguenti, neque sordicies.	 Be careful according to your virtue, so that the wound may be clean during your treatment: neither should there be dirt from ointment, nor dirtiness.
Neque dimittas uirus aggregari in eo omnino: quoniam quando uirus aggregatur super panniculum cerebri, corrumpit eum, et putrefacit ipsum, et accidit super infirmum post illud malicia magna: et iam accidit in siphac capitis, cum mundificatur ab eo os, praecipue quando negligitur cura eius, nigredo in superficie eius.	 You must not let pus gather on it at all, because when pus gathers on the brain tissue, it corrupts it and makes it rot, and after that a great mischief happens to the sick person: and it has already happened in the head wound, when the bone is cleaned by him, especially when care of it is neglected, blackness appears on its surface.
Considera ergo tunc, si accidunt infirmo accidentia quae diximus, scias, quia est pernitiosum proculdubio.	 Therefore, if what I have said happens to the sick person, know that it is certainly dangerous.
Et si nigredo non accidit, nisi a medicina quae ponitur super ipsum, et est in uirtute illius medicinae, ut faciat illam nigredinem: tunc oportet, ut accipias ex melle partem unam, ex oleo rosato partes tres, et linias cum eis pannum.	 If blackness does not happen except from the medicine placed upon it and this medicine is of its nature to cause blackening, then it is necessary that you take one part from honey and three parts from rose oil and wash it with these.
Deinde pone ipsum super siphac: postea cura ipsum cum speciebus curationis quae conueniunt, donec sanetur.	 Then place it on the wound: afterward take care of it with the remedies suitable for healing until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Nasi quando frangitur.	 Chapter on the repair of a broken nose.
Caput IIII.	 Chapter IV.
Scias, quod non franguntur ex Naso nisi duae partes eius superiores simul, aut una earum: propterea, quod ipse sunt duo ossa: quoniam inferius eius est cartilaginosum, non frangitur, et non accidit ei nisi attritio, et tortuositas, et simitas.	 Know that the nose is not broken except by both of its upper parts together or one of them: therefore, because there are two bones in it, the lower part is cartilaginous and is not broken, nor does anything happen to it except abrasion, curvature, and deviation.
Si frangitur una duarum partium eius, tunc oportet, ut intromittas digitum paruum in foramen Nasi, et aeques illam fracturam digito tuo indice, et pollice deforis, donec redeat Nasus super figuram suam naturalem: et fiat illud arte, cum facilitate.	 If one of its two parts is broken, then it is necessary that you insert a small finger into the nose and adjust the broken part with your index finger and thumb on the outside until the nose returns to its natural shape; and this should be done skillfully and easily.
Et caue, ne accidat per operationem tuam illam super infirmum dolor.	 And be careful that no pain happens to the sick person during your treatment.
Quod si fractura est in superiore parte Nasi, et non perueniat ad illam digitus: tunc oportet, ut aequetur extremitate radii, in quo sit grossitudo parua.	 If the fracture is in the upper part of the nose and does not reach it with the finger: then it is necessary that the end of the radius be leveled, where there is a small swelling.
Si uero fractura est in duabus partibus, tunc fac simile illius: et propera cum restauratione eius in die primo fracturae, si est possibile.	 If the fracture is in two parts, then make it similar (to what?); and approach with its restoration on the first day of the fracture, if possible.
Et si non, tunc post diem septimum, aut decimum apud quietem apostematis calidi.	 And if not, then after the seventh or tenth day, at a place of warm plasters (apostematis).
Deinde intromitte in extremitate Nasi licinium ex panno lini, si fractura est in parte una: aut intromite duo licinia si fractura est in duabus partibus: et sit in licinio grossitudo tantae quantitatis, quae impleat foramen Nasi.	 Then insert a piece of linen from a linen cloth into the end of the nose if the fracture is in one part; or insert two pieces of linen if the fracture is in two parts: and let there be a swelling on the linen of such a size that it fills the nostril.
Et dixerunt quidam antiquorum restauratorum, ut infundantur licinia in butyro, et permutentur omni die.	 And some of the ancient restorers said that linen should be soaked in butter and changed every day.
Illud uero non uidetur mihi, imo oportet, ut infundatur licinium in albugine oui, confecto cum puluere molendini.	 But that does not seem to me; rather, it should be soaked in egg white, made with flour mill powder.
Deinde dimitte licinium, donec firmetur os, et induretur cartilago.	 Then release the linen when the bone has hardened and the cartilage has become hard.
Et quandoque intromittitur in Nasum loco licinii penna anseris, postquam inuoluitur super ipsam pannus lenis: et fit, quod ipsa tenet fracturam Nasi uehementius, et ut non prohibeatur infirmus ab inspiratione.	 And sometimes a feather of a goose is inserted into the nose where the linen was, once a soft cloth has been laid over it: and this serves to hold the fracture in the nose more strongly and to prevent weak ones from being prevented from breathing.
Et non est haec res necessaria.	 And this is not necessary.
Si uis, fac illud: et si uis, fac licinia.	 If you want, do it; if you want, do the linen.
Quod si accidat Naso iterum dum operaris apostema calidum, emplastra nasum cum caeroto, aut cum coto infuso in oleo rosato, aut modico ex dyaquilon.	 If it happens again that the nose gets an abscess while working on a warm plaster, apply a nasal embrocation with pitch, or with cotton soaked in rose oil, or a little bit of zinc oxide.
Si autem non accidit apostema calidum, tunc oportet, ut emplastres ipsum cum farina sisami, et puluere thuris confecti cum albugine oui.	 If no abscess occurs, then it is necessary to apply warm plasters with wheat flour and powdered incense mixed with egg white.
Deinde pone super ipsum stuppam lenem, et non liges Nasum cum aliquo omnino.	 Then place a soft cloth on top of it (the wound), and do not tie the nose with anything at all.
Si uero franguntur ossa Nasi fractura parua, aut comminuuntur, tunc oportet, ut scindas super ea, et extrahas ipsa cum instrumentis quae conueniunt eis.	 If however the bones of the nose are broken in a small fracture or crushed, then it is necessary that you cut through them and extract them with instruments suitable for the purpose.
Deinde sue scissuram, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat, et consolidat ex emplastris conuenientibus ad illud, uel unguentis.	 Then suture (the wound) and take care of it with something that promotes healing, such as appropriate plasters or ointments.
Quod si accidat inter Nasum uulnus, tunc oportet, ut cures ipsum cum liciniis: et administres cannulam de plumbo, donec sanetur.	 If the wound is between the nose, then it is necessary to take care of it with linen and administer a lead cannula until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Mandibulae inferioris, quando disrumpitur.	 Chapter on the restoration of the lower jaw when it is broken.
Caput V.	 Chapter V.
Quando disrumpitur Mandibula inferior, et fractura eius non est cum uulnere: conspice tunc si est fractura eius deforis tantum, et non frangitur in duo, et curuatur ad interiora: tunc cognitio eius est facilis.	 When the lower jaw is broken and there is no wound associated with the fracture: examine it then to see if the fracture is only on the outside and not split into two, and curved towards the inside; in this case, recognition of the injury is easy.
Oportet ergo, si est fractura eius in parte dextra, ut intromittas digitum indicem sinistrae in os infirmi: similiter si fractura est in mandibula sinistra, tunc intromitte indicem manus dextrae: et impelle cum eo gibbositatem fracturae deintus cum facilitate ad exteriora cum manu tua altera ab interiori parte ossis decenter, et cum eo aequa ipsam.	 Therefore, if the fracture is on the right side, insert your left index finger into the weak jaw; similarly, if the fracture is in the left jaw, then insert your right index finger; and push with it the bulge of the fracture to the inside with ease towards the exterior using your other hand from the inner part of the bone correctly, and with equal pressure.
Quod si fractura mandibulae iam separata est in duo, tunc oportet, ut administres extersionem a duabus partibus, secundum rectitudinem: donec possibilis sit aequatio eius.	 If the fracture of the jaw has already been separated into two parts, then it is necessary to administer a traction from both parts according to right angle; until it becomes possible to align them.
Si autem iam accidit in dentibus commotio, aut disruptio: tunc stringe illos de quibus speras quod remaneant cum filo auri, aut argenti, aut seta.	 If however it has already occurred that the teeth are displaced or disrupted: then tie them with a gold, silver or silk thread.
Deinde pone super mandibulam fractam caerotum.	 Then place a compress on the broken jaw.
Deinde pone super ipsum pannum duplicatum, et pone super pannum astellam magnam decenter factam: aut frustum cutis soleae aequale, in longitudinem mandibulae.	 Then place a double cloth on the jaw and position a large star-shaped pad made of it centrally over the cloth or an equal piece of sole leather along the length of the jaw.
Deinde liga ipsum desuper, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ligatura eius, et conuenit ipsius applicatio, donec non destruitur: et praecipe infirmo, uti tranquillitate et quiete: et pone cibum eius sorbitiones lenes.	 Then bind it above, as your ligature for it is prepared, and its application fits well until it does not disintegrate; and command the sick one to be at rest and in peace; and place soft foods for his purges.
Si autem estimas, quod iam alteratur aliquid figurae aliquo modorum: tunc propera, et solue ipsum in die tertio.	 If you deem that something changes in the figure by some means: then hurry, and dissolve it on the third day.
Deinde rectifica quod alteratum est ex eo, et emplastra ipsum ex puluere molendini, cum albugine oui, aut cum farina sisami, postquam tu abstuleris caerotum: et pone super emplastrum lanam lenem.	 Then correct what has been altered from it, and plaster it with flour of mill, with egg white, or with wheat flour, after you have removed the soot; and place a soft wool on top of the plaster.
Dum ergo permanet annexum illud emplastrum super ipsum, et non alteratur ossis dispositio, dimitte ipsum, ne soluas, donec sanetur: aut stringe fracturam.	 While that plaster remains attached to it and the bone arrangement does not change, leave it be until it heals; or tie the fracture.
Multotiens enim stringitur haec fractura in tribus septimanis.	 For this fracture is often tied in three weeks.
Quod si interim accidat apostema calidum, tunc administra illud quod diximus multotiens in sedatione eius, donec remoueatur illud apostema.	 If in the meantime a hot abscess occurs, then administer what I have said many times for its soothing until that abscess is removed.
Et si fractura est cum uulnere, considera.	 And if there is a fracture with a wound, be aware of it.
Namsi iam separatur ex osse frustum, aut a satagie: tunc subtilia te in hoc, ut auferas illa frusta satagiae cum eo quod conuenit tibi in ablatione eorum ex instrumentis.	 For if the fragment separates from the bone or a tendon, then be subtle in this matter so that you remove those fragments of the tendon together with what suits you for their removal using your instruments.
Si uero orificium uulneris est strictum, tunc amplifica ipsum cum phlebotomo secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	 If the opening of the wound is narrowed, then enlarge it with a leech according to the amount needed for your purposes.
Deinde quando abstuleris illa satagie, et non remanserit ex eis aliquid, sue tunc orificium uulneris, si est amplum: et si non, pone super ipsum ex emplastris quae conueniunt ad illud, et incarnant illud, donec sanetur.	 Then when you remove the tendon and nothing remains of it, or if the opening of the wound is wide: and if not, place on it plasters that suit for this purpose, and let it heal until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Furculae, quando frangitur.	 Chapter on the repair of a Fork, when it breaks.
Caput VI.	 Chapter VI.
Plurimum quidem frangitur Furcula ab anteriore parte ex parte humeri, et fractura eius fit secundum unum trium modorum.	 The most common break of a Fork occurs from the front part of the shoulder blade, and its fracture is made in one of three ways.
Aut enim frangitur et separatur in duo, praeter quod accidant in ea satagiae: et est facilius ad restaurationem eius.	 For it is broken and separated into two, except that there occur in it pustules: and it is easier for its restoration.
Aut ita, quod accidunt in osse satagiae: et est difficilius ad restaurationem.	 For such as occur in the bone, pustules: and it is difficult for its restoration.
Aut ita, quod est fractura cum uulnere.	 For such as is a break with a wound.
Et operatio in ea quando fractura est absque uulnere, est, ut facias praesentes esse duos ministros, ut teneat unus eorum adiutorium quod sequitur Furculam fractam, et alter extendat collum uersus partem.	 And the operation in it when there is a break without a wound, is that you make present two servants, one of whom holds the aid following the broken beam, and the other stretches the neck towards the side.
Deinde aequa fracturam digitis tuis, donec fiat forma eius, secundum quod oportet: et non sit in ea eminentia, neque concauitas.	 Then with your fingers make equal the break until its form is made, according to what is necessary; and there is not a projection or a hollow in it.
Quod si indiges extensione plus, tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico infirmi spheram ex panno, aut lana: et sit magnitudo eius secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae: et extende, et eleua Furculam, et coarta spheram manu tua, donec aeques fracturam, secundum quod oportet.	 If you need more extension, then it is necessary that you put under the small of the sick person a ball made from cloth or wool; and its size should be according to your necessity; and stretch, raise, and press the ball with your hand until you make equal the break, according to what is necessary.
Quod si non potes trahere extremitatem Furculae ad exteriora: propterea, quia peruenit ad profundum: tunc oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et ponas sub humero eius puluinar medium in magnitudine, et premat minister humerum eius ad inferiora, donec eleuetur os Furculae quod est in profundo ad sursum: atque tunc rectifica fracturam, et aequa eam digitis tuis.	 If you cannot pull the end of the beam outwards because it has come to a depth; then the sick person must lie down on his neck; and put under his shoulder a small board in size, and press the servant's shoulder towards below until the bone of the beam which is in the depth is raised upwards; and then straighten the break, and make equal it with your fingers.
Si autem sentis sathaiatum ex Furcula, et mouetur: tunc oportet, ut findas super illud, et extrahas ipsum alsathaiatum cum facilitate.	 If however you feel a pustule from the beam and it moves; then it is necessary that you pierce it over it, and draw out the pustule with ease.
Si autem est retentum in osse, tunc ingenia in incisione eius cum uno Incisoriorum quae praeparasti ad illud, postquam tu posueris sub Furcula instrumentum quod seruat sifach: et est instrumentum ex ligno, aut ex ferro.	 If however it is retained in the bone; then you make an opening in its incision with one of the cutters which you have prepared for that purpose, after you put under the beam the instrument which protects the saw-horse; and the instrument is made of wood or iron.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its form.
Assimilatur cochleari cui non est concauitas.	 It is to be assimilated to a snail shell without concavity.
Et sit latitudo eius secundum illud quo indiges eo ex magnitudine ossis, et paruitate eius.	 And let its width be according to that which you need for it in proportion to the size of the bone and its smallness.
Longitudo uero eius etiam secundum quod possibile est tibi ad operationem.	 The length [of it] also, as far as possible for you, for the operation.
Et habeat duas extremitates, sicut uides: et extremitas una sit ampla, et altera stricta.	 And it should have two ends, as you see; and one end shall be wide, and the other narrow.
Si autem disruptio uulneris quod scidisti quando extraxisti sathaiatum ossis, est ampla, et securaris ab apostemate calido: tunc aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura.	 If however the wound which you cut when you extracted the splinter of bone is wide, and it gapes open; and there is no adhesion from hot cautery; then collect two lips of the wound with suturing.
Et si disruptio est parua, aut times apostema calidum: tunc imple uulnus cum pannis, et puluillis secundum quantitatem scissurae uulneris.	 And if the wound is small, or you fear hot cautery; then fill the wound with cloths, and with wool according to the size of the wound incision.
Quod si accidat apostema calidum, tunc infunde pannum in oleo rosato, et aceto, et uino, et pone super ipsum.	 If it happens that hot cautery occurs, then soak the cloth in rose oil, vinegar, and wine, and put it on top of it.
Strictura uero ossis quando est absque uulnere, et absque sectione, est, ut ponas super os emplastrum factum ex farina molendini cum albugine oui.	 But the suture of a bone without wound and without cutting is, that you place on it an ointment made from milled flour with white egg yolk.
Et pone stuppam lenem super ipsum.	 And place soft wax over it.
Deinde pone spheram sub titillico eius, si indiges illa.	 Then place a sphere under the fracture if you need it.
Deinde accipe himematem, id est, rotam quam tenent Saraceni, quae sit longa ualde: et sit latitudo eius palmi unius, aut circiter illud.	 Then take a hematic, that is, the wheel which the Arabs hold, which should be very long; and its width should be one palm or approximately that.
Deinde pone puluillum duplicatum super stuppam et emplastrum.	 Then place folded wool over soft wax and ointment.
Deinde accipe astellam ex tabula subtili, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, et in longitudine similiter.	 Then take a needle from thin wood, whose width is three fingers, and similarly in length.
Deinde inuolue eam in panno.	 Then pass it through the cloth.
Deinde inuolue pannum illum cum astella in loco alhimemati qui cadit super fracturam et locum.	 Then pass the cloth with the needle into the place of the hematic which falls upon the fracture and into the wound.
Deinde pone alhimemati super fracturam sicut reuoluiur, et inuolue eam super collum eius, et sub titillico eius sano, et sub titillico eius infirmo: et reduc eam super omnem partem, et quomodo uides quod strictura tenet fracturam strictura decenti: et est illud, quod non occultatur super te, et totum, ut non remoueatur astella desuper os fractum.	 Then place the hematic upon the fracture as it is rolled, and pass it over his neck, and under the healthy part and under the sick part; and draw it over every part, and so that the suture holds the fracture tight; and this is what is not hidden from you, and all of it, so that the needle does not remove the fractured bone.
Et propter hoc oportet, ut aspicias infirmum in omni die.	 It is necessary to observe the sick person every day.
Quotiens ergo mollificatur ligamentum, et uides astellam iam remoueri: tunc rectifica illud, et stringe ligamentum.	 Whenever the bandage becomes soft, and you see the knot moving already, then adjust it, and tighten the bandage.
Deinde pone somnum infirmi super dorsum eius, et pone sub titillico eius apud somnum eius puluinar paruum in nocte, ut cum eo eleuetur adiutorium eius a latere ipsius.	 Then place the sick person's sleep on his back and put a small pillow under his chin near his sleep for the night, so that when he is awakened, help may be brought to him from his side.
Eleuatur ergo fractura furculae per eleuationem humeri.	 Therefore, dislocate the neck-fracture through elevation of the shoulder.
Aut liga brachium eius ad collum ipsius: et non soluas ligamentum, si non accidat in loco accidens ex pruritu, aut ab apostemate, usque ad duodecim dies.	 Or bind his arm to his neck and do not loosen the bandage unless it happens at the place arising from itching or swelling, for up to twelve days.
Deinde renoua emplastrum, si uideris faciem eius ad illud.	 Then renew the plaster if you see his face turning towards that [place].
Et adde in strictura, et dimitte ipsum, donec restauretur et coaguletur.	 And add some [material] in binding and release it until it is healed and hardened.
Et fractura quidem furculae stringitur et confortatur secundum plurimum in uigintiocto diebus: et quandoque fit in quibusdam hominibus in minore illo.	 The dislocated neck is bound and supported for as many as 20 days, and sometimes it occurs in fewer than those [days].
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spatulae.	 Chapter on the repair of a fracture in the flat bone (spatula).
Caput VII.	 Chapter 7.
Raro frangitur Spatula, et in loco lato eius: et non franguntur ex ea nisi margines eius.	 The Spatula seldom breaks, and at its broad place: and from it, only the edges break off.
Quando ergo frangitur ex eo locus, et frangitur in medio eius, et non cognoscitur illud nisi per tactum: tunc secundum quod est figura fracturae conare praeparationem eius.	 When it breaks from there, and breaks within its midst, and is not recognized except by touch: then prepare for its treatment according to the figure of the break.
Et reduc eam super figuram naturalem omni modo ingenii, quod est tibi possibile.	 Bring it back to its natural shape in every way possible that is within your ability.
Deinde pone super locum puluerem molendini cum albugine oui, et stuppam lenem, et pone desuper puluillum ex panno duplato.	 Then place on it a mixture of milled powder with egg white and soft starch, and then cover with a downy cloth.
Deinde pone super ipsum astellam latam ex tabula subtili secundum quantitatem Spatulae totius, aut ampliorem ea parum.	 Then place on top of it a wide star made from thin wood according to the size of the Spatula or slightly larger.
Si uero sub astella est concauitas in aliquo locorum Spatulae, tunc aequa illam concauitatem cum stuppa leni, donec descendat astella secundum aequalitatem.	 If there is a hollow under the star for any part of the Spatula, then fill the hollow with soft starch until the star sinks to the same level.
Deinde ftringe desuper cum alhimemati longa, constrictione decenti, et firmitudine astellae, donec non remoueatur a loco suo.	 Then fix it on top with long alum thread, with suitable tightening and firmness of the star, until it cannot be moved from its place.
Et considera ligamentum in omni die.	 And examine the bandage every day.
Quotienscunque ergo mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum, et aequa astellam si remoueatur a loco suo: et iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	 Whenever the bandage becomes soft, tighten it, and if the star moves from its place, let it lie weak on its healthy side.
Et Spatula quidem restauratur in uiginti diebus, aut in uigintiquinque diebus.	 And the Spatula is restored within twenty days or twenty-five days.
Quando ergo completur iste numerus, tunc solue ligamentum: et tu sis in securitate.	 When this number is completed, then loosen the bandage: and you will be safe.
Nam ipsa est ex ossibus quorum communitio non timetur, neque eorum solutio.	 For it is made of bones whose fracture is not feared, nor their solution.
Si autem procedat ex osse frustum, et pungit sub cute: tune scinde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum.	 If, however, a bone splinter comes out and pierces under the skin: then cut it off above.
Et fac quod diximus in fractura furculae ex sedatione apostematis calidi, si accidat ex eo aliquid.	 And do as we said for the break of a collarbone using a hot poultice, if something happens from it.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Pectoris.	 Chapter on the restoration of the broken chest.
Caput VIII.	 Head VIII.
Pectus quandoque frangitur in medio sui, et raro accidit illud.	 Chest sometimes breaks in the middle, and it happens rarely.
Extremitates eius quidem plurimum franguntur, et comminuuntur ex accidentibus eius.	 Its extremities break or are fractured more frequently due to their accidents.
Quando frangitur eius medium, quod declinat ad inferiora, et accidit ei dolor uehemens, et difficultas in anhelitu, et tussis: et fortasse euomit sanguinem, et declaratur concauitas in osse fracto, et non occultatur sensui, Restauratio eius est, ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et pone inter Spatulas eius puluinar.	 When it breaks at its middle, which declines towards the lower parts, and this is accompanied by intense pain, difficulty in breathing, coughing, and perhaps blood vomiting, and a hollow appears on the fractured bone, which is not concealed to the sense; the restoration is that the weak one lies down with his back upon it, and place between the splints a pillow.
